The MTV Movie Awards, described as not the Oscars, featured fan-voted categories like best kiss and best shirtless performance (won by Zac Efron) and served as a promotional platform for upcoming summer films. "The Fault in Our Stars" won best movie, with Shailene Woodley earning best female performance, Trailblazer Award, and best kiss (shared with Ansel Elgort), dedicating her speech to author John Green. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for "American Sniper," Channing Tatum best comedic performance for "22 Jump Street," and Meryl Streep best villain for "Into the Woods." Kevin Hart accepted the comedic genius award with his children, while Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award alongside his "Avengers" co-stars. Clips from upcoming films like "Pitch Perfect 2," "Trainwreck," and "Avengers: Age of Ultron" were showcased.

Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old Scotland Under-21 international, was loaned from Aberdeen to Dundee United in July and has scored five goals this season; he made his Aberdeen debut in 2012, scoring four times in 89 appearances. St Mirren manager Jack Ross praised Smith as a "brilliant acquisition," highlighting his maturity and value as an attacking option, despite initially doubting the move's feasibility. Bottom-of-the-Championship St Mirren are set to host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council announced that warmer weather has enabled the use of Jetpatcher machines to repair potholes, targeting 145 daily repairs over the next four months, while additional staff will address drainage damage from heavy rain and clear debris from gutters.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors, including rigging supervisor Steve Innes, were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework during shutdown work on EnQuest’s Thistle platform off Shetland. The workers claimed they lacked proper protective equipment (PPE) and were only informed of the contamination later, leading to cancer fears and ongoing blood tests. Innes accused EnQuest of breaching its duty of care. EnQuest stated the exposure was below the reportable threshold (less than 1% of HSE limits) but notified the HSE and implemented additional precautions post-investigation. Wood Group emphasized employee safety, downmanned workers for medical assessments, and supported EnQuest’s investigation. Unite criticized the handling of the incident, calling for transparency, while the HSE confirmed no investigation occurred as the incident wasn’t reportable under RIDDOR and no workers directly reported it.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 in 2007 from New York dealer Art of the Past, whose manager later admitted to trafficking stolen Indian antiquities, including this piece believed to have been looted from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu. Following a 2012 court case revealing the dealer's activities and subsequent discussions between Singapore’s National Heritage Board and India’s Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), which formally requested the sculpture’s return in May, ACM agreed to repatriate it despite lacking conclusive proof of theft, citing the manager’s confession. The sculpture was among 30 items ACM acquired from the dealer, with no others currently identified as stolen, though ASI inspected them. ACM plans legal action to seek compensation for the fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km, felt widely in cities including Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena, causing no immediate injuries or damage but triggering aftershocks, power outages, and phone line disruptions in Garfagnana, where schools were evacuated as a precaution. Italy, prone to earthquakes, experienced a deadly magnitude-6 quake in the same area in May 2022, killing over 20, and the 2009 L'Aquila quake (magnitude-6.3) killed nearly 300, leading to the manslaughter conviction of six scientists and an official for providing misleading risk assessments before that event. The recent tremor was described by INGV as "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow," occurring unexpectedly.

On 8 September 2016, Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, who had been skeptical about South Yorkshire's climate suitability for growing fruit, expressed joy upon seeing unripe fruit still attached to the plant.

Rockstar has delayed the release of its game from 27 January to 24 March, citing the need for additional testing and polish to ensure quality, while emphasizing the decision was made in the best interests of the game and fans. Alongside this, the company announced that online heists will debut on consoles before the PC version, and revealed PC-specific enhancements including 1080p resolution at 60fps, 4K support, and triple monitor compatibility, alongside published minimum system requirements. The game, Grand Theft Auto V, previously set a record as the fastest-selling entertainment product in 2013, earning $1 billion in three days.

The 76-year-old artist Simpson won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work *Squint (19)* at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery, having been shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three other times. Judge Ansel Krut described the painting—depicting a medieval leper squint (holes allowing outcasts to view church services)—as "quite extraordinary" yet "difficult to look at," praising its technical subtlety and emotional depth. Measuring about 7ft (2.1m) tall, the piece was part of a series Simpson was working on; he chose it for the competition due to familiarity and plans to spend the prize on art materials. Established in 1957, the biennial prize counts David Hockney, Peter Doig, and patron Sir Peter Blake (1961 junior winner) among past winners.

Masked assailants simultaneously attacked the offices of Turkish newspapers Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, located 20km apart, early on Thursday, shattering windows with gunfire and leaving spent bullet casings; no casualties occurred, firefighters extinguished a blaze at Yeni Safak, police cordoned off areas and are hunting the perpetrators, with no group claiming responsibility. Both papers support President Erdogan's AK Party, and the incident follows a September attack by pro-government protesters on Hurriyet newspaper over alleged misquotation of Erdogan.

A 24-year-old player, previously under contract with the Stags, has agreed to join Marcus Bignot's side, the Mariners, on a free transfer after spending the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, where he scored three goals in 23 appearances. He will officially become Bignot's first signing for the Mariners on 1 January.

Arsène Wenger, linked with the England managerial role, commented that interim manager Gareth Southgate, appointed after Sam Allardyce's departure, has gained experience and must prove his competency through upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain. Wenger emphasized focusing on his current job at Arsenal, where he plans to extend Hector Bellerin's contract amid transfer speculation, asserting the defender's long-term future remains with the club. He also noted midfielder Aaron Ramsey's continued absence due to a hamstring injury sustained in August.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday, according to officers. Lincolnshire Police are conducting a joint investigation with the Health and Safety Executive, and the company is fully cooperating with the inquiry.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement resolving a dispute over seafarers' pay on freight vessels serving Scotland's Northern Isles, where the RMT union claimed some workers earned under £4 an hour. The freight boats Hellier and Hildasay, operated by Seatruck under contract to Serco Northlink, will return to Serco's direct operation next month. Seatruck had argued the UK minimum wage did not apply to non-UK resident crew, while Serco stated it offered to cover the pay gap retroactively, which Seatruck declined. The new charter, effective early next month pending final financial and regulatory details, ensures all crew receive at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink holds a £243m government-subsidized contract awarded in 2012 to operate ferries and cargo vessels to the Northern Isles.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital six days after a May 7 incident at Rockley Park in Poole, where Jamie Mitchell, 35, intervened in an argument between Dickie and his mother Samantha Mitchell, 57, with whom Dickie had been in a relationship. Jamie Mitchell admitted common assault after a confrontation outside a bar where both men had been drinking heavily; the altercation was initially broken up by the public. Jamie and Samantha Mitchell also pleaded guilty to attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying to police, initially claiming Dickie pushed Samantha and she pushed back, but Jamie later stated he caused a "tragic accident" while trying to separate them. Both await sentencing on February 6.

Rod Temperton, the British songwriter known for penning Michael Jackson's hits like "Thriller," "Rock With You," and "Off the Wall," died at 66 in London after a brief battle with cancer. Nicknamed "The Invisible Man" for his low profile, Temperton began his career in the disco band Heatwave, writing their 1970s hits "Boogie Nights" and "Always & Forever." His work caught producer Quincy Jones's attention, leading to contributions on Jackson's breakthrough solo albums *Off the Wall* and *Thriller*, the latter becoming the best-selling album in US history. Temperton also wrote for artists like Anita Baker and Donna Summer, won a Grammy for "Birdland," and received two Oscar nominations for *The Color Purple* soundtrack. Tributes from Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, and others highlighted his profound influence on music. Born in Cleethorpes, he credited his father’s early introduction to radio for his songwriting passion, famously prioritizing creating music that emotionally resonated. His family requested privacy following his private funeral.

A team including Swansea University's Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott discovered over 450 ancient geometrical earthworks, potentially 2,000 years old, in Acre state, Brazil, previously hidden under bamboo-dominated rainforest until recent deforestation. These geoglyphs, likely not villages or defensive structures due to sparse artefacts and layout, may have been used sporadically for rituals, akin to Stonehenge or Maya pyramids, though Loader's analysis of soil samples, phytoliths, charcoal, and carbon isotopes revealed they were constructed amidst taller vegetation, making them invisible above the canopy and raising questions about their function. The research challenges assumptions of pristine pre-European Amazonian ecosystems, indicating human influence over 6,000 years through selective cultivation of valuable species like palms, creating a "prehistoric supermarket" of forest products, with evidence suggesting modern biodiversity in Acre's forests may still reflect these ancient agroforestry practices.

Nick Kyrgios, ranked a career-high 12th, defeated Sam Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round, following his recent Japan Open victory. Kyrgios admitted to feeling tired and bored during the match, citing fatigue from travel and poor sleep due to the lengthy commute to Shanghai's Qi Zhong Stadium, located an hour from the city center. He also referenced a previous $1,500 fine at the Shanghai Masters for a foul-mouthed outburst where he called the tournament a "circus."

The HPV vaccine, currently administered to girls aged 12-13 in Wales to prevent cervical cancer, is advocated by scientists and charities to also protect against rising head and neck cancers linked to the sexually transmitted virus, particularly affecting younger, non-smoking men (average age 55). Charities including Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru, and Cardiff University's HPV research team are urging the Welsh government to extend vaccination to boys, citing HPV's role in 5% of global cancers and emphasizing the need for proactive public health measures. While 85% of Welsh girls have been vaccinated since the 2008 rollout, the Welsh government awaits recommendations from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before deciding on program changes.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old diagnosed with rare gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, passed away after a public battle documented on his "Jak's Journey" Facebook page, which garnered over 28,000 Likes. He briefly attended a school prom held in his honor, where his family collected his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity, but left early due to illness. His mother announced his death on social media, expressing pride in his resilience. Jak shared updates on his treatment, meetings with sports figures like Rangers FC players, hospital stays, and personal moments. After doctors in January revealed his cancer had spread and halted treatment, Jak vowed to fight, while his family encouraged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. Despite his prognosis, he participated in cherished experiences, including outings with his girlfriend and events with celebrities, with a charity football match planned to raise further funds.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 in a match with few chances, as Mohamed Salah assisted Abdallah El Said's late 89th-minute winner after Uganda had a Joseph Ochaya goal disallowed for offside earlier in the second half. The result eliminated Uganda from their first tournament since 1978, while Egypt will face Ghana to decide Group D's top spot after Ghana secured a quarter-final place with a 1-0 win over Mali. The game featured a resilient Ugandan defense, a deteriorating pitch, and limited attacking threat, with Egypt struggling to break through until Salah's composed pass set up El Said's decisive finish.

Lancashire County Council has identified land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College sites for a potential railway station, following a Network Rail study comparing these locations with one near the Concourse shopping centre. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961 and one of the largest in northwest England without a station since its original closed in 1956, could receive two direct hourly trains to Liverpool under plans developed with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council. The preferred site, owned by the council, offers space for future expansion, good highway access, and connectivity to the town, prompting the authority to begin land acquisition processes.

During a Saturday morning search of a warehouse near Ashbourne, police discovered plants in what they described as "an elaborate grow house," leading to the arrest of a man in his late 40s at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, was found seriously injured on a pavement late Sunday after being dragged by the neck through several streets; she underwent emergency surgery and was transferred to a specialist clinic. Her 38-year-old ex-partner from Bad Muender surrendered to police and is in custody; both are German citizens of Kurdish origin. Authorities have not determined the motive, secured the crime scene, and requested witness information.

A study by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, analyzing 4,600 Australian workers, found that women request pay rises as frequently as men but are 25% less likely to receive one when asking, contradicting the "reticent female" theory. The research, using 2013-14 Australian workplace data—unique in systematically tracking pay rise requests—controlled for factors like part-time status, employer size, industry, parental status, and qualifications. It found no evidence that women avoid asking due to fear of upsetting employers or gender stereotypes. Researchers suggested potential discrimination, noting men might underreport unsuccessful requests. However, among workers under 40, both genders asked and received raises at equal rates, indicating a possible shift in negotiation behavior, with younger women potentially achieving greater success as they advance.

Oxford City Council has spent funds on ground investigations for new burial sites but found no suitable locations due to size, ground conditions, high water tables, or legal restrictions, with existing cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley expected to be full by 2018 and 2021 respectively; after these are full, only reopening family plots, using reserved plots, and interring ashes will be possible, as the last burial space expansion occurred in 1932, and the council continues searching despite land scarcity within Oxford.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from 19 to 22 July, will feature an augmented reality app allowing visitors to access online content like videos and band interviews by scanning items such as signs and posters, enhancing on-site experience and enabling global interaction with real-time updates, ticket purchases, and festival atmosphere previews, as highlighted by director Caroline Maclennan, with performances by acts including The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Peatbog Faeries.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred racehorse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham, with the British Horseracing Authority attributing his death to a rare "severe pulmonary haemorrhage" unrelated to underlying health issues. Though he had previously experienced post-race ataxia symptoms like overheating and wobbling, he showed no such signs on the day of the race. Trainer Oliver Sherwood called him the "horse of a lifetime," referencing his past victories including the 2015 Gold Cup trial and 2014 Hennessy Gold Cup. The BHA emphasized the rarity of such incidents but committed to further research into prevention, while confirming his death was not linked to his prior overheating condition.

Davina Ayrton, previously known as David, a 34-year-old defendant with learning difficulties, was remanded into custody at a male prison in Winchester after denying raping a 15-year-old girl in a Portsmouth garage in 2004 while two others slept; the victim recalled clearly shouting to stop the attack despite minimal alcohol consumption. Judge Ian Pearson cited substantial risks of self-harm and non-attendance if released, noting the case's unusual nature, with sentencing scheduled for 4 March. During the trial, Ayrton discussed her sexuality, stated she had made no physical changes or taken medication, and changed her name in 2012; the court heard she disclosed the attack to a care home worker in 2014 and attempted suicide in summer 2023, prompting specific detention protocols.

Novak Djokovic and his Serbian doubles partner were defeated by Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares (6-4, 6-4) in Rio, occurring a day after Djokovic's singles loss to Juan Martin del Potro; this followed Djokovic's unexpected third-round Wimbledon exit to Sam Querrey in July, though he later secured his 30th Masters title in Toronto prior to the Olympics.

The annual chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, will feature over 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US, who use only chainsaws to sculpt logs into animal and human figures; last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, returns to defend his title and retain the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, who has been sidelined since September with a serious foot injury sustained in a World Cup warm-up match, is nearing a return and aiming to regain fitness ahead of the Six Nations starting in February. The 27-year-old Welsh scrum-half, currently in a pre-season phase, expressed optimism about his progress and hopes to return slightly earlier than the initial February target after discussions with physios. Wales' Six Nations campaign begins on 7 February against Ireland. Webb, capped 16 times, recently renewed his dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, rejecting other offers to remain with his home region, where he debuted in 2007, citing his commitment to both club and country.

On Tuesday morning near Sumas, Washington, US border agents encountered two men carrying backpacks containing 58lb of ecstasy, interrupting a smuggling attempt from Canada to San Francisco; one suspect, Jeffrey Laviolette, was arrested immediately, while the other fired at agents and fled, leading to a manhunt resulting in Canadian Nathan Hall's arrest. Investigators also arrested Kali Henifin, who planned to pick up the men, and her boyfriend Ryan Lambert, who was to be paid $11,000 to transport the drugs; all three US defendants face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges, with the area noted as a known smuggling route for drugs and firearms.

Childline reported counselling over 4,500 children for online abuse in the past year, a significant increase from 2,400 in 2011-12, with victims as young as seven experiencing torment, abuse, and fear of attending school. The charity highlighted the pervasive impact of cyber-bullying, which extends beyond school into home life, causing persistent persecution. Dame Esther Rantzen urged adults, parents, and schools to intervene, stressing that bullying escalates without action. The findings, released during Anti-Bullying Week, involve collaborative efforts by the Anti-Bullying Alliance. A testimonial revealed a child's distress after being told to kill themselves online, with parents underestimating the emotional toll, while affected youth advised on coping strategies.

Israel postponed a vote on authorizing 492 new settlement homes in East Jerusalem at Prime Minister Netanyahu's request, aiming to avoid escalating tensions with the US ahead of Secretary Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. This followed a UN Security Council resolution, which the US abstained from, condemning Israeli settlements as illegal and a barrier to peace—a move Netanyahu angrily rejected, accusing the US of orchestrating the resolution, a claim denied by the State Department. Netanyahu retaliated by summoning ambassadors of Security Council nations supporting the resolution, recalling Israeli envoys from New Zealand and Senegal, cutting aid to Senegal, and canceling a visit by Ukraine's prime minister. Kerry's speech was expected to outline a peace vision and counter Israeli critiques of the Obama administration, while Palestinian President Abbas viewed the resolution as a step toward a January peace conference in France seeking a mechanism to end occupation.

Prince William praised the Queen as a "guiding example" of monarchy in a BBC interview ahead of her 90th birthday, addressing criticism of his own royal workload by stating he takes duty seriously but seeks to develop into his role gradually. Commemorative stamps featuring four generations of royals (the Queen, Prince Charles, Prince William, and Prince George) were released, while the Queen participated in Windsor events including a Royal Mail visit marking its 500th anniversary and opening a bandstand with schoolchildren singing. Prime Minister David Cameron lauded her service with "dignity" at PMQs. Birthday celebrations included a Windsor walk unveiling a plaque for The Queen’s Walkway, lighting a beacon to trigger global tributes, and a lunch with the Obamas. The republican group Republic criticized the BBC's coverage as excessive and unbalanced.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in an EFL Cup match, with Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scoring first-half goals from Sam Byram's pass and a low cross respectively. Despite Cheltenham's efforts, including Harry Pell's volley and Jordon Forster's header, they failed to seriously test West Ham's goalkeeper Adrian. West Ham made seven changes from previous Premier League fixtures and missed further chances, including James Collins and Byram's attempts, while Cheltenham's best opportunity saw Dan Holman narrowly miss connecting with Pell's volley. The result eliminated League Two's last representative from the competition, marking the teams' second meeting after West Ham's 2-1 win four years prior.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion when Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, failed to see his motorcycle while turning right in a VW Transporter. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court, receiving a £1,000 fine and a two-year UK driving ban. The victim's family opposed jail time, acknowledging the crash resulted from a momentary lapse, while Werner's defense highlighted his remorse and inability to explain the incident.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from London, became one of the most dangerous British jihadists returning from Syria, where he joined the Islamic State-affiliated group Rayat al Tawheed, creating propaganda videos and appeals for donations to recruit young British Muslims. After over a year in Syria, he attempted to return to the UK in June 2014, faking his death online and seeking help from his cousin Tahir Bhatti, who admitted assisting him. Arrested upon arrival at Dover, Khawaja pleaded guilty to four terrorism-related offenses and faced potential life imprisonment, having been held in a high-security unit at Belmarsh Prison due to his perceived danger. MI5 monitored his activities, including his involvement in gruesome propaganda, such as posing with a severed head, though his exact motives for returning remain unclear.

Kayden Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, who finished eighth, and has joined Barnsley as their third signing ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday. Jackson rejected a contract offer from Wrexham, with Barnsley caretaker manager Paul Heckingbottom praising his pace, attacking style, and suitability for the team's playing approach.

Sealed bottles of detergent, some leaking, have washed up on Cornish beaches including Poldhu Cove, Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove, and Marazion, prompting cleanup efforts by National Trust volunteers due to wildlife risks; while the National Trust suspects a container from the MV Blue Ocean—lost near Land's End in May during storms—as the source, the Maritime and Coastguard Agency notes this link remains circumstantial. Cornwall Wildlife Trust expressed high concern over marine life impacts, with authorities monitoring beaches and advising the public to avoid contact with bottles; Vanish, the detergent manufacturer, has not yet commented.

A crash occurred around 14:00 on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness, resulting in minor injuries to several people; the road was closed with diversions via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road, and Police Scotland confirmed ongoing inquiries into the incident.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back who joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 total appearances, played 14 times last season as Bolton secured promotion to the Championship by finishing second in League One, with manager Phil Parkinson praising his late-season contributions; Dervite has now signed a new contract alongside teammates David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan following their promotion.

Lib Dem Lord Oates criticized Labour for conceding too much on Brexit, while Labour's Baroness Smith accused the Lib Dems of offering "false hope," highlighting tensions after their initial collaboration to defeat the government on EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal collapsed when MPs rejected those amendments. Labour accused the Lib Dems of "grandstanding" for campaign material, while Lib Dem Baroness Ludford accused Labour of enabling a "hard Brexit" by aligning with the government. Despite a history of alliances on issues like higher education and housing, a Labour source predicted "residual tensions," doubting future social cooperation though both parties committed to maintaining business-like relations.

Defence is a low priority in the UK election, with parties offering minimal manifesto detail despite global instability and military cuts reducing the regular Army to 82,000, the Royal Navy to 19 warships, and the RAF to eight fast jet squadrons, creating capability gaps like reliance on NATO for submarine patrols. UK defence spending has fallen to sixth globally, below the NATO 2% GDP target, risking credibility with allies like the US, and further cuts are likely as no major party ring-fences defence, though some resist deeper reductions. Trident renewal is divisive, with Conservatives and UKIP backing full replacement, Labour considering three submarines, Lib Dems ending continuous patrols, and SNP/Green scrapping it, while new aircraft carriers face crewing and aircraft shortages, highlighting concerns over a "hollow force".

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, but additional costs including signing fees, wages, agent fees, and a recent tax payment brought the total to £106.8m, amid allegations the actual transfer cost was higher than initially stated. The club denied any tax-related crime but made a supplementary tax payment of €13.5m to address potential divergent interpretations of contracts, while maintaining their original payment complied with obligations. A Spanish judge ruled sufficient evidence exists to continue investigating the transfer, following the resignation of former president Sandro Rosell, who faces accusations of misappropriation but denies wrongdoing. The case's status post-payment remains unclear.

Michael Luciw, 27, from Nottingham, died in a motorway collision caused by Albert Kenneth Newman, who was driving the wrong way; both died. Luciw's family called for mandatory regular driving tests for older drivers, arguing that aging slows reactions, while Age UK emphasized the importance of elderly drivers maintaining independence. Luciw, a new father described as generous and kind-hearted, was a passenger in a van driven by colleague Andy Harrington, who sustained serious injuries and also advocated for medical exams for retired drivers. The UK currently requires drivers over 70 to self-renew licenses every three years without medical or driving tests; the DVLA stated no age-based restrictions are planned, citing no evidence of higher accident risk among older drivers and noting licenses can be revoked for medical issues.

The passage discusses safety concerns over transvaginal mesh implants in Scotland, where many women have suffered debilitating side effects, leading to legal action by over 400 against health boards and manufacturers. An independent review faced controversy, with two patient representatives resigning over a perceived watered-down report, and a consultant later quitting over concerns. The report recommended against routine use for pelvic organ prolapse, advised offering alternative treatments and informed choices, and called for mandatory adverse event reporting, though campaigners sought a ban. Health Secretary Shona Robison stated the Scottish government lacks authority to ban the procedures, which falls to the UK's Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency. Review chairwoman Tracey Gillies apologized for failing to achieve consensus, facing public criticism during her testimony, while Prof Alison Britton will examine the review process for future lessons. Over 20,000 Scottish women have received the implants in the past two decades, with significant complications reported.

Laura Muir broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old indoor 5,000m record by 14 seconds with a time of 14:49.12 in Glasgow, though McColgan initially questioned whether the race met UK Athletics criteria as Muir was the only 5K competitor in a mixed 3K/5K event and raised concerns about drug testing protocols. British Athletics confirmed the record's expected ratification, noting no doping control requirement if absent at the event. McColgan praised Muir's potential to reach world-leading times like 14:30, comparing her solo race to her own record-setting experience 25 years prior, and highlighted Muir's Scottish heritage while emphasizing her need to refine race tactics for global medal success, referencing Muir's previous 1500m British record and Olympic final appearance.

Jung won gold riding Sam, a replacement horse after Fischertakinou's infection, while France's Astier Nicolas secured silver and American Phillip Dutton bronze; Britain's William Fox-Pitt, competing 10 months after an induced coma from a fall, finished 12th despite a faultless final show-jumping round, having dropped from first after dressage to 21st due to cross-country penalties. Ireland's Jonty Evans placed ninth.

Andy Murray defeated Fabio Fognini 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5 in a tense Wimbledon match lasting two hours and 39 minutes, saving five set points in the fourth set to avoid a decider and advance to the fourth round, where he will face Benoit Paire. Despite inconsistent play and fading light, Murray rallied from 5-2 down in the fourth set, capitalizing on Fognini's errors and a point penalty for an obscenity. Murray acknowledged the match's challenges but expressed relief at finishing without a roof delay, while Johanna Konta also progressed to the second week with a straight-sets victory.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014 at 06:00 BST, with police later finding people still present and till receipts indicating alcohol sales until 04:49 BST; the judge ordered a three-month closure, charged license holder Colleen O'Neill (43) with two counts and James Thomas (44) with one count of permitting liquor consumption outside licensing hours, noting O'Neill's "appalling record" and fining her £3,000 and Thomas £1,000, while a defense solicitor acknowledged licensing laws were not strictly followed and the bar operated improperly into early morning.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionists, faced scrutiny after stating voters should prioritize Ulster Unionist candidates first, then transfer votes to candidates they trust, including nationalists like the SDLP, which he preferred over Sinn Féin for post-election partnership. His remarks drew public disagreement from senior colleague Danny Kennedy, but Nesbitt dismissed regrets, citing support from unionist areas and confidence in his stance. The party’s "Real Partnership" manifesto focused on healthcare waiting lists, increasing police numbers, infrastructure, LGBT rights, and Brexit protections, while framing the election as a referendum on DUP-Sinn Féin governance failures, including the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal and alleged incompetence and corruption. Nesbitt aimed to shift focus back to these issues amid controversy over his transfer comments.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden confirmed a legislative consent motion will be presented to the Northern Ireland Assembly to pardon men convicted of abolished sexual offences, aligning with England and Wales' "Turing's Law" provisions, which grant posthumous pardons and allow living gay and bisexual men to apply for pardons; the motion, secured with executive agreement, aims to ensure equal treatment and expedite resolution compared to a full assembly bill, with arrangements to be implemented promptly.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, set a new Scottish 1500m record of 4:19.12 by finishing second behind Faith Kipyegon, surpassing Yvonne Murray's 1994 record (4:22.60) and moving to second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd (4:17.57). Muir, who holds Scottish records in the 1500m and mile, expressed pride in the achievement, noting it was her first race of the season at that distance and highlighting her proximity to Kipyegon's performance. Murray congratulated her via her husband's Facebook post. Muir aims to secure a spot for the Rio Olympics at the upcoming British trials in Birmingham, following an 800m victory in France and ahead of a 1500m race in Stockholm. She balances training with veterinary studies, having recently completed her fourth year.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell asserted that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi lacked personal motives for Alexander Litvinenko's 2006 murder, implicating the Russian state as the likely sponsor due to Litvinenko's defection in 2000, his criticism of President Putin, and his accusations against the FSB. Litvinenko died after ingesting polonium-210-laced tea during a meeting with the suspects, with Horwell citing the radioactive substance as evidence of state involvement, though not directly linking Putin. The suspects left a polonium trail, denied wrongdoing, and remain in Russia after failed extradition attempts. Horwell noted unknown public health risks from the radiation, revealed Litvinenko was poisoned twice before death, and highlighted the inquiry's adjournment, with Kovtun criticized for not testifying.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed captain of Australia's one-day and Twenty20 teams in Aaron Finch's absence, with David Warner, 28, as vice-captain despite past disciplinary issues, following Michael Clarke's retirement after the Ashes defeat. National selector Rod Marsh praised Smith's talent and readiness to succeed Clarke, noting Warner's maturity and leadership potential. Smith previously captained during Clarke's injury, boasting 2,952 runs in 32 Tests at a 54.66 average. The pair will lead Australia in limited-overs matches post the final Ashes Test.

Tim Farron, the Liberal Democrat leader, repeatedly refused to state whether he believed homosexual sex was a sin during media appearances, responding instead that "we are all sinners," while asserting his strong commitment to LGBT+ rights, including defending equal marriage and extending transgender marital rights by addressing the spousal veto issue. He defended his 2007 vote against the Equality Bill—which aimed to reduce discrimination against gay people—by citing concerns about "protection of individual liberties" after his party’s amendment was defeated, though he emphasized his support for legal equality regardless of sexuality.

French-based Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site in 2015, cutting 450 jobs, but Accord Healthcare will now use the plant for pharmaceutical production, potentially rehiring many former Sanofi employees. Accord, a global pharmaceutical company producing over 130 products for around 60 countries, expects the investment to positively impact the area, with Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes praising the move for boosting the local economy and reinforcing the region's reputation in the science and healthcare sector.

Richard Ellis is leaving the council at the end of his contract, while Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are departing through voluntary redundancy and early retirement. Ellis served as interim director of corporate governance and deputy chief executive, Monaghan led the chief executive's office, and Sutherland headed human resources and customer services. SNP opposition leader Stephen Flynn cited these exits as evidence of the council's difficulty retaining senior staff and anticipated more departures. Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the three for their dedication and professionalism.

Militants attacked Sardar Daud Hospital in Kabul using explosives and gunfire, killing and wounding staff and patients, with over 50 injured; Afghan commandos killed all four attackers after hours of fighting. The Islamic State (IS) claimed responsibility, while the Taliban denied involvement, and President Ghani condemned the assault as a violation of human values. This marked IS's first direct engagement with security forces in Kabul, employing Taliban-like tactics (blowing gates), suggesting expanded capabilities and a shift from previous civilian targets like Shia gatherings. Despite government claims of rooting out IS from eastern bases, militants remain in mountainous areas. IS, active in Afghanistan since declaring its "Khorasan Province" in 2015, has conducted multiple major attacks, including a 2016 Kabul rally bombing and recent Supreme Court carnage, while the Taliban continues its own offensive, including recent Kabul suicide attacks.

English rider Martin crashed at this year's TT with his Honda Fireblade experiencing mechanical issues, initially announcing his retirement from road racing before clarifying he hasn't quit racing entirely but has no plans to race Hondas this year. He skipped the North West 200 after teammate John McGuinness's practice crash and withdrew from the Ulster Grand Prix following Cadwell Park testing where he determined the bike wouldn't be competitive, a decision the team made without informing him. Martin described the TT as disastrous, feeling reduced to a test rider, and expressed no unfinished business in road racing, preferring classics and "oddball" events instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured 19 of 28 declared governorships in Nigeria's elections, marking the Peoples Democratic Party's (PDP) worst defeat since 1999, following its loss in the presidential poll to APC's Muhammadu Buhari. The PDP lost key northern states, including Katsina and Kaduna, and Adamawa, a Boko Haram-affected region, but retained Rivers State and eight governorships, mainly in the south-east. The APC's gains, including Lagos, relegated the PDP to a regional stronghold in the south-east and Niger Delta, though it failed to win any oil-producing states, raising concerns about potential militant disruptions to oil revenue. Elections were marred by violence in some areas, notably Rivers, but were overall more peaceful than previous years. The PDP's decline is attributed to corruption allegations, defections to the APC, and failure to address insurgency, necessitating party rebuilding.

Mighty, a US environmental group, accused Olam and its major stakeholder Temasek of enabling unsustainable palm oil practices contributing to regional haze by allegedly sourcing from rogue suppliers, though both companies denied the claims. Olam, which sources 99% of its palm oil from third parties and holds less than 1% of the global market, defended its "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy, agreed to disclose its 14 suppliers after initial resistance, and stated non-compliant suppliers would be removed, though vetting would take years. Temasek, Singapore's state fund, distanced itself from Olam's operations, emphasizing governance principles. The report also criticized Olam's deforestation in Gabon for palm oil plantations, but Olam asserted its practices there were responsible and transparent, aligned with Gabon's sovereign rights. The palm oil industry faces broader accusations of environmental harm and labor issues, with tensions between green groups and executives over enforcement challenges and economic trade-offs.

On 27 August 2016, a restaurant started offering puppy platters following the introduction of a new law permitting dogs to dine at outdoor restaurant areas, with the scene humorously described as resembling a "dog's dinner" and accompanied by a reference to a related clip.

Fernando Forestieri is a doubt due to a knee injury, having been limited to substitute appearances in the last two games, while Derby County's David Nugent may return from a groin injury that kept him out of the previous match. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield, who scored a late equalizer off the bench, is pushing for a starting recall.

Pakistan's telecom regulator lifted the ban on YouTube after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version, though YouTube denied granting authorities content-filtering capabilities. While many young Pakistanis welcomed the move, activists demanded transparency regarding the deal's terms. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority directed providers to restore access, and the IT ministry stated Google would allow PTA to request blocking of offending material, subject to Google's review based on community guidelines and local legality, with such requests documented in YouTube's Transparency Report. The ban, imposed in 2012 following protests and deaths over the blasphemous "Innocence of Muslims" film, was lifted as Google expanded local YouTube services to Pakistan, Nepal, and Sri Lanka.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, faces demands from Liberian FA president Musa Bility to step down due to sharing Swiss-Italian nationality with presidential candidate Gianni Infantino, citing FIFA's Electoral Regulations (Article 7.4) on conflict of interest, as Scala had withdrawn in 2015 when Swiss Sepp Blatter was a candidate. Scala's spokesman Andreas Bantel argues no regulation mandates withdrawal for shared nationality, stating the 2015 move was voluntary to avoid perceived conflict with an incumbent, and insists no conflict exists now with five non-incumbent candidates. Bility threatens to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not resign by Thursday, emphasizing the election's integrity after FIFA's turmoil. The election, involving five candidates including Infantino, Prince Ali, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale, occurs on February 26 in Zurich. Bility, barred from running, supports Prince Ali.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed in an explosion while working in a paint-spraying area at Harford Attachments in Spar Road shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday; their bodies were removed Tuesday afternoon. Forensic evidence suggests a flashover explosion caused by a buildup of toxic fumes and an ignition source, creating a fireball effect. The company manufactures digger buckets, and investigations by police and the Health and Safety Executive, including forensic inquiries, witness statements, and electrical safety inspections, are ongoing.

Tunisia avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations by apologizing to CAF for complaints about refereeing during their contentious 2015 quarter-final loss to hosts Equatorial Guinea, where a disputed penalty led to their elimination and subsequent accusations of poor officiating, though they denied alleging corruption. Morocco's participation in 2017 qualifying was reinstated after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned a CAF ban and reduced their fine from $1 million to $50,000; the ban stemmed from Morocco's refusal to host the 2015 tournament over Ebola fears, leading to Equatorial Guinea's last-minute hosting. Both nations are now included in the 2017 qualifiers, with Tunisia in Group A and Morocco in Group F, and Tunisia could set a record with a 13th consecutive finals appearance if they qualify.

A mass fracas occurred during the Chelsea vs. Manchester City match at Etihad Stadium, resulting in Chelsea's 3-1 win, with City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho sent off—Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct against David Luiz (his second dismissal this season), while Fernandinho was banned for three matches after clashing with Cesc Fabregas, who faced no further action. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's role, and both clubs must respond to the charge by 18:00 GMT on 8 December.

Wales and parts of the UK have some of the worst cancer survival rates in the developed world, prompting a pilot scheme in Cwm Cynon and Neath targeting patients with suspected cancer but no urgent symptoms, following a visit by Welsh doctors to Denmark, where diagnostic systems improved survival rates. The concern is that Welsh patients without clear symptoms face long waits for diagnosis due to not fitting specific treatment pathways, leading to multiple referrals and delayed treatment, often when cancer is advanced. The pilot allows 40 Cwm Cynon GPs to refer patients to a diagnostic center at Royal Glamorgan Hospital within seven days, aiming to assess six patients weekly with same-day tests, hoping to increase early diagnosis rates beyond the current 35% for concerning symptoms in Cwm Taf. A similar clinic will open in Neath Port Talbot Hospital as part of another trial by Swansea Bay health board, developed after Welsh specialists visited Aarhus, Denmark, which established diagnostic centers due to poor survival rates. Dr Gareth Davies and GP Gareth Jordan highlight the scheme’s potential to expedite diagnosis, reduce patient anxiety, and improve outcomes through rapid assessment. If the six-month pilot succeeds, other local health boards will offer the service.

England defeated Pakistan by a significant margin at Old Trafford to level the series, declaring at 589-8 and 173-1, marking their second-largest run victory over Pakistan. Joe Root, named man of the match, scored 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, took four catches, and claimed a wicket, earning praise from captain Alastair Cook, coach Trevor Bayliss, and commentator Michael Vaughan for his disciplined performance after addressing errors from the first Test. Pakistan struggled, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the series; Misbah cited poor shot selection and low confidence, while Geoffrey Boycott noted their broken spirit and predicted further England dominance. Vaughan suggested the series could remain tight, with the third Test at Edgbaston following Pakistan's tour game against Worcestershire.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand with Rob Howley as part of his backroom team, while Robin McBryde steps in as Wales' head coach for the third time, having previously led tours in 2009 and 2013, expressing enthusiasm for the role; the Welsh Rugby Union is finalizing assistant coaches for the summer tour to support McBryde, with CEO Martyn Phillips noting advanced discussions to confirm the management team soon, and chairman Gareth Davies highlighting the developmental benefits for Welsh coaches and rugby from the Lions' New Zealand tour, emphasizing its potential to inspire and challenge individuals.

Hull City came from behind to defeat Southampton 2-1, ending a six-game losing streak despite losing strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane to first-half injuries. Southampton led early through Charlie Austin's penalty, but Robert Snodgrass—substituted for Keane—scored and assisted Michael Dawson's header within two second-half minutes to turn the game. Southampton pressed for an equalizer, but Hull goalkeeper David Marshall made crucial saves, and Sam Clucas cleared a last-minute shot off the line. The win lifted Hull's morale amid fan discontent and a sparse crowd, though they remain in the relegation zone. Both managers acknowledged the match's intensity, with Hull's Mike Phelan praising his players' resilience and Southampton's Claude Puel criticizing his team's loss of concentration after their midweek Europa League win. Hull next face Sunderland, while Southampton host Liverpool after the international break.

A fatal collision occurred around 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton near Woodhall Spa, resulting in the death of a local motorcyclist, though no further details were released; the tractor driver involved was unharmed. Lincolnshire Police appealed for witnesses and closed the road in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into abuse of power allegations revealed by covert recordings, stating he aimed to "defend national interests" and end turmoil ahead of early elections, a move condemned by opposition leader Zoran Zaev—who called it illegal and urged protests—and EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn, who warned it jeopardized Macedonia's EU aspirations. The crisis, ongoing since 2015, stems from recordings allegedly exposing government corruption, including vote-rigging, murder cover-ups, wiretapping of 20,000 individuals, fund mismanagement, and politically motivated prosecutions, which the government denies while accusing Zaev of attempting to destabilize the country.

Following Bob Bradley's dismissal, Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea's upcoming match against Bournemouth, with the club aiming to swiftly appoint a new manager, prioritizing ex-Derby boss Paul Clement. Curtis emphasized the urgency of avoiding relegation, highlighting the Championship's increased competitiveness and Swansea's potential struggle to retain top players if demoted, making an immediate return unlikely. Reflecting on Swansea's rise from near-bankruptcy in 2003 to Premier League promotion in 2011 and their reputation for attractive football, Curtis noted a decline since Michael Laudrup's 2014 departure, attributing it to frequent managerial changes and a dilution of the "Swansea Way," alongside inadequate player replacements. Despite this, he believes the current squad can survive relegation and educates new signings on the club's history, stressing the importance of Premier League survival for both the club and the local community.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated to the National League after a 3-2 defeat to Leyton Orient, despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona overturning an initial 2-0 deficit, with Armand Gnanduillet scoring Orient's winner; this loss confirmed relegation for Dagenham, who have struggled defensively (League Two's worst goal difference) and offensively (Cureton scoring only nine goals compared to 20 in 2014-15), under manager John Still, who previously led them to League One but now aims for promotion next season. Orient's victory kept their play-off hopes alive, leaving them two points adrift, amid managerial turmoil after Kevin Nolan's recent removal, with interim boss Andy Hessenthaler stressing professionalism and fan commitment, while Still criticized his team's lack of organization and discipline in their decisive defeat.

Steven Gerrard, the 36-year-old former Liverpool captain, will return to the club as a youth coach in February, marking his first role since retiring as a player after a 19-year career that included winning the Champions League, UEFA Cup, FA Cup, and three League Cups. Liverpool manager Jürgen Klopp praised Gerrard's ambition to become a future manager, emphasizing the importance of combining his playing experience with coaching education. Gerrard, who left Liverpool in 2015 for LA Galaxy and retired in November, had been linked with the MK Dons managerial position but felt it was "too soon"; he is currently working towards obtaining his UEFA A coaching license, required for Premier League management.

Morton opened the scoring with McManus netting from close range at the 15-minute mark, followed by Ross Forbes doubling their lead with a deflected strike; Alloa pulled one back before halftime through Kyle McAusland's shot, but McManus scored again and Denny Johnstone added a late goal to secure a comfortable home win for Morton.

Ofsted uncovered children being taught in squalid conditions in three now-closed Birmingham locations, part of an investigation into 18 unregulated schools, primarily in Muslim communities in the Midlands, with owners facing potential jail terms for running illegal schools. Sir Michael Wilshaw, expressing serious concerns about child abuse and radicalization risks, described these cases as the "tip of the iceberg" and criticized officials for slow action and confusing advice. The government is consulting on stricter regulation for institutions teaching over 6-8 hours weekly, with mandatory registration required for those operating over 20 hours. While some part-time centers legally support home-educated children, Ofsted suspects others exploit home-education rights to run illegal schools. A dedicated team of six inspectors will investigate such schools across all religious groups, and the Education Secretary has directed Ofsted to prepare prosecution cases, requiring her consent for legal action, alongside an ongoing consultation until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, located at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, operates on a small scale with one of the UK's smallest production stills in a cowshed, distinguishing it from other proposed distilleries aiming to establish the region's first whisky distillery since 1837. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes emphasizes using locally sourced botanicals from the Teviot valley to capture the Borders' "terroir" and reflects the area's potential as a "region of distilling excellence." John Henderson of Born in the Borders notes the distillery complements the on-site brewery and aligns with their local sourcing ethos. The gin is named after Lilliard, a legendary 16th-century Borders heroine linked to the nearby Battle of Ancrum Moor, chosen to honor the landscape and the female production team.

Gary Green, 51, was jailed for 16 months and two weeks after reversing a vehicle into Harry Whitlam at Swithens Farm in August 2013 while more than twice the legal alcohol limit, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer. Prosecuted under health and safety legislation due to the incident occurring on private land, Green admitted failing to ensure others' safety. The Health and Safety Executive found he backed the tractor into Whitlam in a closed-off area. Harry's mother described the family's enduring grief and hope to remember his life beyond the accident, while the HSE inspector called Green's actions reckless and the case extremely tragic.

The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) partially upheld Luis Suarez's appeal against his FIFA ban for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup, reducing the suspension to allow him to train, play in friendlies, attend matches, and participate in promotional activities, though he remains banned from competitive matches until October 26 (his likely Barcelona debut in El Clasico) and must serve an eight-game international ban. CAS deemed FIFA's original total football ban "excessive," as it hindered his post-suspension readiness, but upheld the core sanctions, disappointing Fifpro, which argued for further reductions tied to mandatory treatment. Suarez's legal team called the appeal a success, claiming FIFA misapplied rules and imposed a disproportionate penalty, while the striker—a repeat offender with prior biting and racial abuse suspensions—apologized days after initially denying the incident.

On 18 March 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race against Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene, after training for a week on a local athletics track. The 380-meter course involved hurdles, a steep slope, and water pistols, with competitors not required to be married—participants included men carrying women, men carrying men, and a woman carrying a woman. Rich noted the Lithuanians provided tough competition, and the pair will advance to the World Championships in Finland in July.

The UK government's plan to replace paper car tax discs with an electronic system in October 2014 raised concerns about potential job losses among the 5,000 DVLA employees in Swansea, but Transport Minister Stephen Hammond assured that while job roles would change due to reduced refund processing and new systems, any workforce reductions would be managed through redeployment to other business areas rather than redundancies. Swansea East AM Mike Hedges welcomed these assurances, acknowledging the benefits of monthly direct debit payments and eliminating tax discs while expressing disappointment over reduced job opportunities at the DVLA.

Hungary's Foreign Minister Péter Szijjártó asserted that the EU should not interfere in domestic matters, stating Hungary would not backtrack on its controversial laws regarding asylum seekers, NGOs, and higher education, which the EU opposes. He cited Poland's pledge to veto any EU attempt to strip Hungary of voting rights, a process requiring unanimity. The laws include strict asylum controls involving container housing (questioned under EU law), a higher education law threatening George Soros-founded Central European University, and pending NGO legislation criticized for stigmatizing groups as "foreign-backed." Thousands have protested these laws, while the EU Commission has warned of potential action if Hungary does not address concerns.

Emma Thompson will portray Mrs. Potts, originally voiced by Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version, while Kevin Kline plays Maurice, Belle's father, in the live-action adaptation of "Beauty and the Beast," set for US release on 17 March 2017. Emma Watson stars as Belle, with Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. Directed by Bill Condon, filming begins in May at Shepperton Studios.

Adrian Gill, a renowned Sunday Times columnist diagnosed with multiple cancers, passed away, prompting tributes from colleagues who hailed him as a brilliant, fearless writer and the "heart and soul" of the paper since 1993. Known for his dazzling wit and controversial articles—including offensive remarks about Wales, Norfolk, and the Isle of Man, and a censured comment about Clare Balding—Gill overcame dyslexia to build a celebrated career, dictating his copy. His personal life included marriages to author Cressida Connolly and former Home Secretary Amber Rudd, with whom he had two children, and an engagement to partner Nicola Formby before his death.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa from the band Khar Sarnai, was allegedly attacked after performing in Ulan Bator while wearing a traditional robe embroidered with a swastika—a symbol in Mongolia predating Nazi association. Reports state he was struck with a bottle, kicked in the face, and spent 10 days in a coma with serious brain injuries. His father and lawyer denied social media claims that he shouted "Heil Hitler," emphasizing the swastika's cultural significance. The suspect, an unidentified Russian diplomatic officer, was not detained, with police citing the injury's non-serious nature and denying diplomatic immunity influenced the decision. The Russian embassy called local press reports "distorted" but confirmed an investigation, while Sukhbaatar's lawyer demanded accountability under Mongolian law.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid protested against airport expansion by staging a demonstration on the northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday, leading to charges of aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area; the protesters will appear in court on 19 August, and the Metropolitan Police stated airport security would be reviewed.

Glamorgan's innings was anchored by Nick Selman's 101, his second first-class century, marking a return to form after a slump, supported by Aneurin Donald's brisk 36, while seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets in favorable bowling conditions; Gloucestershire faced a challenging evening session, ending the day evenly poised, with Selman reflecting on overcoming early struggles and Taylor acknowledging the bowler-friendly pitch and his own successful strategy of targeting the stumps, as Glamorgan, led by stand-in captain Michael Hogan, secured a consolation bonus point.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after making online threats to the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee about planning a false crime report to lure and ambush police officers at the Dee Estuary, intending to shoot them; he admitted two charges in Mold Crown Court, with sentencing pending. Prosecutors stated Hughes, drunk during the threats made on two occasions, had a prior 2009 firearm conviction and was on bail for unrelated firearms offenses (later cleared) at the time, though his defense claimed he had no intent to carry out the threats or harm himself.

Surrey posted 255-7 against Yorkshire, driven by a 130-run partnership between Davies (featuring a six and 10 fours) and Ben Foakes (90), after Yorkshire dropped Davies on 43. Yorkshire's chase faltered due to Stuart Meaker's three-wicket burst (including Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance), despite Tim Bresnan's 68, ending at 236 all out. Surrey's Gareth Batty praised the team's resilience and the pivotal Davies-Foakes stand, while Yorkshire's Alex Lees lamented missed opportunities despite strong bowling, acknowledging their top-order batsmen's failure to deliver in crucial moments.

A 56ft converted trawler, located 6 miles west of South Stack, radioed Holyhead coastguards at 07:00 BST reporting that its onboard pump was overwhelmed by incoming water; the RNLI lifeboat crew provided an additional pump and towed the vessel safely to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old Scottish middle-distance runner, will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to her final-year veterinary medicine exams in May, conflicting with the April event. Despite her disappointment, she prioritizes completing her degree. Muir recently finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the 5,000m. She expressed satisfaction with her performance, highlighting future potential, and aims for two or three more Olympics. While ruling out the Commonwealths, she considers the March World Indoor Championships a potential target, balancing intense study commitments with training, and remains optimistic about competing in Birmingham.

Liverpool's current struggles contrast sharply with last season's title challenge, attributed to the loss of key strikers Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge (who scored 52 of 101 league goals), inadequate replacements like Mario Balotelli and Rickie Lambert, reduced attacking intensity, ineffective midfield runs, and persistent defensive issues despite significant spending on players like Dejan Lovren. Steven Gerrard remains crucial but faces physical and mental challenges at 34, particularly after his costly slip against Chelsea last season. Ahead of the Chelsea match, Robbie Savage suggests dropping Lovren for Kolo Toure and emphasizes defensive solidity, but predicts a Liverpool loss due to Chelsea's superior form. While Champions League qualification would be a success, unrealistic fan expectations persist after last season's overachievement.

A £45m facility planned for Kilmarnock's Sutherland Drive will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre, with East Ayrshire Council seeking permission to name the campus after William McIlvanney, a renowned writer born and educated there. McIlvanney, initially an English teacher before becoming a full-time writer in 1975, gained fame for works like the Laidlaw trilogy, earning the title "Godfather of Tartan Noir," and contributed to Scottish cultural life through poetry, journalism, broadcasting, and political and sporting commentary until his death in December.

An evacuation occurred near a swimming pool in Gourock due to the discovery of a deteriorated British sea mine from the 1940s or 1950s, prompting residents in three streets to leave their homes while those within 500m were advised to stay indoors, open windows, and avoid going outside; exclusion zones were established on the river and a half-mile radius at sea, disrupting ferry services from Gourock and Rothesay. Authorities stressed the evacuation was precautionary with no immediate danger, and the Royal Navy's Northern Diving Unit moved the unstable mine to a safer location due to uncertainty about its remaining explosives, with Inverclyde Council thanking residents for their patience during the operation.

UK Sport has allocated £345m for 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports ahead of Tokyo 2020, £2m less than Rio, with funding cuts affecting archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, and badminton—the latter despite winning a bronze medal in Rio—while cycling's funding was reduced by over £4m. Badminton England criticized the decision as "incomprehensible," questioning the withdrawal after meeting medal targets, whereas judo, which also won bronze, received a slight increase. UK Sport prioritizes medal potential, aiming for 51-85 Olympic and 115-162 Paralympic medals, defending cuts as necessary to avoid underinvestment and underperformance. Team sports like basketball, handball, and volleyball, previously defunded, accuse UK Sport of neglecting their development despite its own review recommending support. Funding for newly added Olympic sports (baseball/softball, karate, skateboarding, sport climbing, surfing) and Paralympic sports (Para-taekwondo, Para-badminton) remains unconfirmed, with £9m yet to be allocated pending medal potential assessments.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff conservation area will be demolished to build a six-storey, 90-room hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks (nine and seven storeys, totaling 122 units), despite objections from English Heritage and the Ancient Monuments Society, who argued the development's scale would cause "severe harm" to the area's historic character. The local council approved the project with a 7-3 vote, citing tourism benefits and the need to replace buildings deemed no longer functional, though 49 residents objected while 246 letters supported the plans. Planning board chair David Kelsey acknowledged the loss of buildings and trees was regrettable but emphasized progress for tourism and elderly living.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old Royal Gibraltar Regiment soldier from Carrickfergus, was fatally attacked by Jake Vallely during an off-duty night out in Brecon on 8 May, after training exercises. CCTV showed Vallely punching Boyd unconscious outside The Cellar bar, beating him until motionless, then dragging his body away; Vallely had been drinking for seven hours and boasted about being the "hardest man in Brecon" beforehand. Vallely, 24, was convicted and faces sentencing on 8 December, while his friend Aaeron Evans was acquitted of manslaughter as he had left before the attack. Dyfed-Powys Police condemned the "despicable act," urging people to avoid violence, while Boyd’s family described him as a loving, promising "all-rounder" whose death left an unfillable void, emphasizing Brecon’s community support as the true strength contrasting Vallely’s claim.

Andrew Travers departed Barnet Council by "mutual agreement" following an error that led to voters being turned away from all 155 polling stations due to missing names on electoral lists, prompting an independent investigation. The council acknowledged Travers' contributions during his tenure, with Deputy Chief Executive John Hooton appointed as temporary replacement. On election day, many voters, including 27 of the first 30 at one station, were initially unable to vote, leading to council apologies, emergency proxy votes, and public concerns about the fairness of the results. Travers attributed the issues to electoral registration lists, while the council's ongoing review, set to conclude by May's end, will examine the incident and assess preparedness for the June EU Referendum, with the investigation's leadership still under discussion.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1, with Josh Gillies opening the scoring via a free-kick before Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham with another set-piece; Ryan Bowman secured the win for Gateshead by heading in Craig Baxter's cross. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's second-half improvement and highlighted the quality of Bowman's goal, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment over his team's inconsistent second-half performances and missed chances despite acknowledging Gateshead's well-executed goals.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014, which evaluates the social and economic well-being of individuals over 60 across 96 countries, ranked Norway first, while Afghanistan was last, followed by Mozambique, as reported on 1 October 2014.

The OneWeb project, in partnership with Airbus, aims to deploy a global broadband satellite network starting with at least 600 spacecraft and potentially expanding to over 2,000, focusing on connecting schools worldwide. To achieve this, Airbus has revolutionized satellite manufacturing by adopting high-volume, low-cost assembly line techniques—producing three satellites per shift at under $1 million each—with initial production in Toulouse, France, and a planned facility in Florida. The constellation requires over 20 Soyuz rocket launches, targeting 300 satellites in orbit by late 2020, 600 by late 2021, and over 800 by mid-decade. OneWeb emphasizes first-mover advantage, having secured $1.7bn in equity, and operates under UK licensing, highlighting economic benefits and regulatory leadership. Debris mitigation commitments include deorbiting satellites within two years using enhanced hardware and adapter devices for potential removal. While this approach may not apply to all space missions, Airbus and OneWeb aim to leverage their manufacturing model for other clients.

Mr Swinney criticized the UK government's spending review for imposing "unprecedented pressure" on Scotland's public finances, projecting a 12.5% real-terms reduction in Scotland's discretionary budget by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11, with 4.2% of cuts still to come, amounting to over £1bn. He argued the UK government could have reduced debt and deficit without such severe austerity and pledged to protect schools, hospitals, and police services, citing past achievements like increased police numbers and free university tuition. The UK government countered that Scottish ministers would have £390m more next year (£750m including underspend), emphasizing the stability of the £30bn block grant and contrasting it with the risks of independence. Labour's Jackie Baillie accused Swinney of "anti-austerity posturing" without substantive alternatives, urging long-term budget planning and different tax decisions.

The passage discusses the need for Changing Places toilets, which offer more space and facilities like hoists for people with severe disabilities who cannot use standard accessible toilets, highlighting campaigns by families like Lorna Fillingham and Alison Beevers to make these facilities compulsory in larger buildings such as shopping centers and stadiums. Current UK guidelines recommend but do not require these toilets, leading to challenges in existing buildings due to size (12 sqm) and cost, though examples like Arsenal Football Club demonstrate successful implementation and positive public response. The lack of such facilities causes significant emotional distress and social isolation for affected individuals and their families, as they often resort to unsanitary alternatives or restricted outings.

Italian consumer organizations have filed a formal antitrust complaint with the European Commission accusing McDonald's of abusing its market dominance by imposing excessive rents and fees on franchisees, restricting them with longer-than-average contracts and above-market lease rates, allegedly leading to higher prices and reduced consumer choice in franchised outlets compared to company-owned stores. McDonald's defended its practices, stating it shares risks and rewards with franchisees, a model it claims supports business opportunities and customer experience. The complaint is backed by unions including SEIU and the UK's Bakers Food and Allied Workers Union, urging an investigation. The European Commission will assess the submission, with powers to launch an inquiry if justified. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's European restaurants, contributing $9.27bn to the company's 2014 global revenue.

A 13-year-old boy, Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve after doctors discovered and removed a large tumor and five smaller growths during a planned appendix operation at Belfast's Royal Victoria Hospital. His family received widespread global support through a viral social media campaign initiated by Bangor Elim Church, where his father serves on the pastoral staff, using the hashtag #prayforjosh on Facebook and Instagram. The church's senior pastor, Gary Beattie, expressed shock at the campaign's reach, with a post shared 948 times and viewed by over 79,000 people worldwide. A mystery donor funded a billboard displaying the hashtag near Holywood's A2 road, and Josh's classmates at Bangor Grammar School joined the online support effort.

The UK government's military restructuring includes closing Brecon Barracks, a historic site operational since 1805, prompting strong opposition from local MP Chris Davies, who cites its long service in conflicts and potential harm to Brecon's economy and military tourism, despite assurances that civilian and military jobs (85 and 90 respectively) are safe; nearby Sennybridge training ground and Dering Lines infantry school remain unaffected, while Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon announced a new light infantry centre at St Athan, with Cawdor Barracks closing in 2024 and a Sennybridge depot in 2025, and Labour's Nia Griffith acknowledged the need for restructuring but warned of uncertainty for affected communities.

The House of Lords European Union Committee warns that UK fishing communities, which strongly supported Brexit to escape the EU’s Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and regain control of UK waters, risk being marginalized in Brexit negotiations despite the industry’s small economic contribution (0.5% of GDP, 12,000 jobs). The report highlights challenges, including shared fish stocks with EU states, reliance on EU exports, and potential trade-offs where EU access to UK waters might be demanded in exchange for tariff-free fish sales to the EU market. It recommends retaining some CFP elements, like science-based quotas, and notes Brexit could fragment fisheries management across the UK’s four nations. While the industry remains optimistic, citing recent EU quota increases as positive signs for post-Brexit independence, the government emphasizes balancing single market access with reforming fisheries management for sustainability and fair quota access.

Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, leaked documents revealing extensive US surveillance programs, including the NSA's access to vast amounts of personal data like phone records, social media activity, and internet communications via Prism, which allegedly provided "backdoor" access to servers of major tech companies like Google and Facebook—though these firms denied involvement. The US government defended the surveillance as vital for national security, with officials like James Clapper and Keith Alexander stating it prevented terrorism, while critics, including Snowden and Privacy International, condemned the privacy violations. Data protection laws vary globally, but the US Patriot Act and FISA Amendments allow authorities to access data stored by US companies, even for non-Americans, raising concerns from the EU and others about citizen rights. Snowden, motivated by privacy fears, emphasized his opposition to pervasive surveillance, stating he did not want to live in a society where all actions are recorded.

OpenAI, backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, aims to advance AI research for positive human impact without financial constraints, focusing on safely benefiting humanity. While figures like Musk and Stephen Hawking warn AI could become an existential threat by outpacing human evolution, others deem such risks remote. OpenAI's mission emphasizes distributing AI benefits broadly and safely, with only a small portion of its $1 billion funding to be spent initially.
