L/Bdr Ben Parkinson, seriously injured in a 2006 Afghanistan bomb attack, carried the Olympic torch in June 2012, receiving thousands of Facebook friend requests exceeding the platform's 5,000 limit, prompting suggestions to create a public page. His nomination highlighted his resilience, humor, and dedication to rehab, gym work, and fundraising for military charities like the Pilgrim Bandits. His mother noted overwhelming support, including 19,000 website hits, increased mail, and hundreds of requests for torch appearances. The Olympic torch relay involved 8,000 bearers over 70 days before the London Games.

In 2011, the U.S. poverty rate remained at 15%, with 46.2 million Americans in poverty, halting three consecutive years of increases, though real median household income declined by 1.5%. The poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021, while income inequality, measured by the Gini index, rose by 1.6%—the first annual increase since 1993. The percentage of uninsured Americans decreased to 15.7% from 16.3%, and poverty had previously peaked at a record 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler moved from Somerset to Lancashire in 2013, signing a contract extension until 2019; he holds England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball century against Pakistan. Ashley Giles, Lancashire's cricket director and head coach, praised Buttler's talent, his impact in the 2015 T20 Blast final victory, and his positive influence in the squad. After playing for Mumbai Indians in the IPL, Buttler will return for Lancashire's T20 Blast match against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates—HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall—are moored in Portsmouth Harbour awaiting sale, with no preservation bids submitted by the January 23 deadline. Interested bidders are finalizing proposals, with viewings scheduled for late February and March, and a decision expected in spring. The government's Disposal Services Authority aims to allocate at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess domestic recycling capacity. Local MP Penny Mordaunt supports UK recyclers but advocates preserving one vessel as a reef diving attraction for tourism revenue, emphasizing emotional ties to the ships. The Ministry of Defence prioritizes taxpayer value, considering all options while maintaining commercial confidentiality. These frigates, originally anti-submarine vessels, evolved into versatile combatants with advanced systems and crew capacities of about 280. The sale follows HMS Ark Royal's 2012 scrap sale for £3 million.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced ongoing racial and political tensions, marked by coups in 1987, 2000, and 2006, which overthrew Indian-dominated governments, entrenched indigenous Fijian political supremacy, and caused economic damage, particularly to tourism, and international isolation, including a 2009 Commonwealth suspension. Following a 2012 commitment to democratic elections in 2014, Fiji was reinstated into the Commonwealth, and Australia and New Zealand restored diplomatic ties. The population, primarily on Viti Levu and Vanua Levu, is divided between indigenous Fijians (now a slight majority due to Indo-Fijian emigration post-coups) and Indo-Fijians, with deep segregation and minimal integration, alongside small minority communities. Despite a diverse economy including sugar, tourism, mining, services, and light manufacturing, Fiji faces persistent trade and budget deficits, making it a major per capita aid recipient.

Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated the country is committed to destroying its chemical weapons per the UN-backed plan but missed a deadline to hand over its stockpile, citing attacks on shipments by "terrorist groups" during transport to Latakia port. He rejected US criticism over barrel bomb attacks in Aleppo, which activists claim killed hundreds, including children, and denied government forces target civilians, accusing the US of supporting terrorists. Conflicting reports emerged about Aleppo's central prison, with rebels claiming control after an assault that freed detainees, while Syrian state media denied the seizure. Syria has removed only 4% of its 1,300-ton declared chemical stockpile, prompting US and Russian concerns over delays, though Mekdad reiterated Syria's commitment to meeting its obligations by the June destruction deadline despite security challenges acknowledged by the OPCW.

The Booker Prize shortlist features Neel Mukherjee's "The Lives of Others" as the 5/2 favourite, alongside works by Howard Jacobson ("J"), Ali Smith ("How To Be Both"), Joshua Ferris ("To Rise Again at a Decent Hour"), Karen Joy Fowler ("We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves"), and Richard Flanagan ("The Narrow Road to the Deep North"), with the winner to be announced at London's Guildhall. This marks the first year the prize is open to all English-language authors globally. Fowler's novel leads in sales (55,000 copies), while Mukherjee's saw a post-shortlist surge from 97 to 507 weekly sales. Criticism emerged over omitted titles, and Jacobson's "J" faced debate about its readability. The judging panel, chaired by AC Grayling, will award £2,500 and a bound edition to each shortlisted author, with the ceremony broadcast by the BBC.

A celebrity identified as PJS is appealing a Court of Appeal decision that lifted an injunction preventing his identification in English and Welsh media regarding alleged extramarital activities, with the Supreme Court set to determine whether to hear his appeal and decide its outcome while maintaining an interim injunction until the hearing concludes. The Court of Appeal had allowed publication after Wednesday 13:00 BST, citing widespread dissemination of the story internationally and online—despite PJS's efforts to remove content—rendering confidentiality "probably lost" and maintaining the ban a "hopeless task." The case stems from The Sun on Sunday seeking to publish allegations involving PJS's past sexual encounters with individuals AB and CD, initially blocked by an injunction granted after a High Court refusal but overturned by the Court of Appeal due to the information's extensive leakage.

Fosse Park, located near M1 junction 21 and opened in 1989, was purchased for £345.5 million in August, with new owners planning improvements to parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of retail units. Blaby District Council leader Ernie White noted the owners engaged with the council to resolve planning concerns, emphasizing Fosse Park's role as a key gateway into the city that requires aesthetic upgrades beyond its current "backs of sheds" appearance. Paul Clarke of Crown Estates highlighted addressing parking and congestion issues, alongside revitalizing tired common areas and facilities to enhance the site's overall quality.

The live-action remake of "Beauty and the Beast" faced controversy in Malaysia over a "gay moment" involving LeFou's feelings for Gaston, leading Disney to delay its release for content review despite the Malaysian Censorship Board approving it with a minor edit related to the scene. Homosexuality is illegal in Malaysia, though the tourism minister criticized banning the film as "ridiculous." The film received a P13 classification, and while the board confirmed approval, local cinemas offered refunds as a new release date remained unannounced. Public backlash included social media criticism, with one viral tweet condemning the decision as hypocritical compared to local films.

Landlords in Southampton must license Houses of Multiple Occupation (HMOs) for properties with more than three unrelated tenants, but many avoid the £1,000 licence fee despite facing fines up to £20,000, with an estimated 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Shelter reports frequent tenant concerns about eviction and poor maintenance due to the affordable housing shortage, receiving 5-6 daily calls. While national HMO licensing applies to three-storey properties with five or more unrelated occupants, Southampton's rules cover specific areas designated in 2013 (Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling) and 2015 (Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, Bassett). The council states most landlords cooperate, but prosecutions have been secured against one firm and 13 individuals.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny (Fine Gael) and Micheál Martin (Fianna Fáil) aim to prevent a second election, with Fianna Fáil offering to facilitate a minority government but refusing to support its program, particularly due to disagreements over water charges—Fianna Fáil seeks their immediate abolition while Fine Gael supports retaining them, leading to proposals for a commission on Irish Water's future; following an election nearly two months prior, Fine Gael holds 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and Labour 7, resulting in a hung parliament where no party secured a majority or successfully elected a taoiseach.

The ferry Sorrento, en route to Valencia, caught fire on a car deck near Mallorca, leading to an evacuation of passengers and crew onto lifeboats; they were rescued by the ferry Puglia, with at least three injuries reported, one serious. The fire's cause remains unknown, and multiple ships assisted in the rescue. Spanish authorities stated the Sorrento might sink, and passengers were being transported to Palma de Mallorca for psychological support. The Italian-owned vessel issued distress signals, and despite initial hopes to avoid abandonment, intense flames necessitated full evacuation.

The Electoral Commission reported 38 MPs raised concerns about potential double voting, a criminal offence, and called for better integration of local electoral registers to identify duplicates, while Labour cautioned against measures that could hinder young voter registration. A record 46.8 million people were registered for the June 2017 election, with a 68.7% turnout—the highest since 1997—and 2.9 million applications submitted during the six-week campaign period, including surges after the snap election announcement and before the deadline. Despite significant electorate growth in student-heavy constituencies, duplicate applications (estimated at 30-70% due to separate, unconnected local and online registration systems) created administrative and financial burdens. The watchdog recommended clearer online information and verification tools, noting the ease of online registration led to duplicates despite efforts to inform voters they need not re-register if already eligible. While some (e.g., students, second-home owners) can legally register in multiple constituencies, voting twice in a general election is illegal, and the fragmented register system prevents cross-checking; solutions proposed include allowing voters to pre-select a constituency. Labour emphasized prosecuting double voting but opposed blanket bans on dual registration, arguing it would disenfranchise those needing multiple addresses for work or study.

Lawrence Phillips, a 40-year-old former NFL player and University of Nebraska star in the 1990s, died by suicide in prison, where he was serving a sentence exceeding 30 years for assault convictions, including hitting teenagers with his car and attacking an ex-girlfriend. His career with teams like the St. Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers ended in 1999 amid ongoing off-field issues. Recently accused of murdering his cellmate, Damion Soward, Phillips faced a trial after a judge found sufficient evidence. His Nebraska coach, Tom Osborne, noted Phillips' intelligence and positive traits but acknowledged unresolved anger and personal struggles.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and official soldier in the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal by Brigadier Andrew Williams at an event in Chester celebrating the regiment's eighth anniversary, recognized for "good behaviour." He is the 30th mascot ram in a lineage tracing back to the 1858 acquisition of the first Private Derby by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot during the Indian Mutiny War, continuing with the Mercian Regiment formed in 2007. Joining in February 2014, he holds an army number, receives pay for rations, and spends mating season holidays on the Chatsworth Estate. His duties have included switching on Ashbourne's Christmas lights and meeting Prince William at a 1914 Christmas Truce memorial unveiling.

Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 Europa League victory over Borussia Dortmund with a last-minute Dejan Lovren goal, completing a remarkable comeback from a two-goal deficit early in the match, echoing their iconic 2005 Champions League final turnaround. Manager Jürgen Klopp's philosophy of transforming doubters into believers was central to the win, as Liverpool overcame Dortmund's initial dominance through sheer determination and key contributions from Philippe Coutinho, Mamadou Sakho, and Divock Origi, whose recent form highlighted his growing importance. The emotionally charged Anfield atmosphere, featuring an extended rendition of "You'll Never Walk Alone" and a Hillsborough disaster tribute, played a significant role in unsettling Dortmund. While defensive vulnerabilities remain a concern, Klopp's impact on the team's identity and fan connection was evident, boosting Liverpool's prospects of winning the Europa League and securing Champions League qualification. Klopp's leadership, including symbolic gestures like banning players from touching the "This Is Anfield" sign without prior trophies, underscored his transformative influence.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee, UK Brexit Secretary David Davis emphasized the government’s commitment to keeping Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed through regular meetings and a "two-way information flow" to incorporate their views into UK-EU negotiations, aiming for a constructive collaborative approach. However, Scottish Minister Michael Russell criticized the UK government’s lack of transparency on key strategic issues, particularly its unclear stance on single market or customs union membership, which he deemed vital for Scotland’s economy, demanding greater clarity. Meanwhile, the UK government hopes to overturn a High Court ruling on triggering Article 50 via an upcoming Supreme Court appeal, but the Scottish government plans to oppose this by seeking representation in the case through its top law officer.

A flock of 13 cloned sheep, including four (Debbie, Denise, Diane, and Daisy) cloned from the same adult ewe as Dolly—the first cloned mammal—are being studied at the University of Nottingham to assess whether cloning causes premature aging. Led by Professor Kevin Sinclair, researchers conduct rigorous health assessments, including joint examinations, X-rays, and fMRI scans, focusing on age-related conditions like osteoarthritis, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes. Dolly’s early death at six-and-a-half years, partly due to osteoarthritis, raised concerns about cellular aging transferred during cloning. The study aims to determine if cloned animals age normally; current results indicate the clones, now aged nine to ten, are healthy, with findings set to be published soon.

Shutter Speed, trained by John Gosden and ridden by Frankie Dettori, won the Musidora Stakes on soft ground, marking Gosden and Dettori's fifth victory in the race; she will bypass the Epsom Oaks (where stablemates Enable and Coronet are contenders) for France's Chantilly Oaks over a mile and a quarter, with Gosden noting a month to prepare. Tasleet, trained by William Haggas and ridden by Jim Crowley, comfortably won the Duke of York Stakes. Gosden expressed concerns about the soft ground for his colt Cracksman in Thursday's Dante Stakes, a key Derby trial, and will decide his participation after walking the course, citing the tight 16-day gap between the Dante and the Derby as a potential factor in skipping the race.

The British pound experienced volatility, initially slipping against the dollar and euro before a mid-afternoon recovery and subsequent decline, with losses of 0.2% against the dollar ($1.4226), 0.6% against the euro (€1.2605), and 1% against the yen; market uncertainty, reflected in a volatility index reaching 2008 crisis levels, was driven by polls showing the Leave camp leading in the EU referendum and Betfair's implied Remain probability dropping to 68.5% from 80%. Analysts predicted heightened sterling volatility as the vote neared, with hedge funds short-selling the currency and Asian markets (Nikkei down 3.5%, Hong Kong down 2.5%) reacting to Brexit fears; London's FTSE 100 fell 1.1%, led by Lloyds Banking Group's 4.2% drop. Leave campaigner Nigel Farage argued sterling had strengthened since March and that a weaker pound benefited exporters, citing April's narrowed UK trade deficit due to rising exports.

The Iron are sixth in the National League, one point outside the play-off spots, after a loss to Barrow, who extended their unbeaten league run to nine games; despite Braintree's three-game losing streak, manager Cowley praised his part-time team's remarkable season but acknowledged the significant challenge ahead, emphasizing their determination to embrace the difficulty.

The passage discusses the transfer of planning decision authority from Northern Ireland's central Planning Service to local councils starting April 2015, allowing elected politicians to approve or reject developments, which is seen by PLACE's Michael Corr as a democratic opportunity for localized planning but raises concerns from Friends of the Earth about potential bias, historical discrimination parallels, and risks from close developer-politician relationships, emphasizing the need for transparency and strict conduct codes, alongside debates over political donation disclosure limits and security concerns, with the Northern Ireland Secretary holding authority to decide on donation transparency timing.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times with an airgun, resulting in a leg amputation, and found injured by her owner Sarah Nisbett in Winchburgh; the Scottish SPCA highlighted the incident to urge airgun licensing, citing public safety risks and irresponsible use, though a previous government consultation saw 87% opposition to such licensing plans, with critics deeming them excessive. The charity appealed for information to identify the shooter.

Christian Benteke joined Liverpool as their second most expensive signing on a long-term contract after the club activated his release clause, becoming their seventh summer acquisition following Raheem Sterling's £49m sale to Manchester City. The 24-year-old Belgian international, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Aston Villa, aims to help Liverpool win trophies, addressing their goal-scoring struggles from last season when they finished sixth due to Luis Suarez's departure, Daniel Sturridge's injuries, and poor returns from Mario Balotelli and Rickie Lambert. Manager Brendan Rodgers reinforced the attack with Benteke, alongside other signings like Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and returning loanee Divock Origi. Benteke, who overcame a 2014 Achilles injury to score 15 goals for Villa last season, was praised by former Villa boss Paul Lambert as a "brilliant number nine" capable of thriving with service, while ex-Liverpool striker John Aldridge highlighted his physical presence and dismissed concerns about fitting Liverpool's style, expressing optimism for improved attacking output.

A study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found no clear evidence that tablet devices improve academic results, despite their rapid growth in classrooms, with 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools using them to some extent, and 9% providing individual tablets per pupil, particularly in academy schools. The number of tablets in schools is projected to rise from 430,000 in 2014 to nearly 900,000 by 2016. While researchers could not isolate technology as a direct cause of academic improvement, head teachers reported positive impacts, including increased pupil motivation and family engagement when tablets were taken home. A separate study indicated touch-screen devices aid reading among boys and disadvantaged pupils. The research highlighted extensive technology integration in young people's lives, with many pupils using internet-connected devices in bed for social media or videos, and 70% of children aged 5–15 having home tablet access. Simon Mason, a school head advocating tablet use, emphasized their role in modernizing education and fostering pupil empowerment, though academic benefits remain difficult to quantify.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs spanning from the 1880s to the 1990s, documenting children's lives and social history in Liverpool, highlighting changes in childhood experiences and special occasions. Key images include an 1887 portrait of the Rollo siblings dressed for a fancy dress ball and a circa 1900 photo of a young maid, reflecting both play and child labor. Curator Kay Jones selected these images from extensive archives to depict diverse childhood experiences, aiming to balance joyful memories with the realities of hardship, such as children working; the exhibition runs until 25 September.

Anderson, 27, terminated his Barrow contract to join a National League rival, potentially facing his former club on 18 February, while 21-year-old striker Keating, recommended by Micky Adams, joined the Gulls pending international clearance after spells in Ireland. Gulls manager Kevin Nicholson highlighted Anderson's leadership qualities and Keating's hunger, with the team currently four points above relegation after one win in six games.

Bolivia's new law permits 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, reflecting the country's economic needs as one of South America's poorest nations, while also imposing harsher penalties for violence against children, including a 30-year sentence for child homicide. Signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera in President Evo Morales's absence, the legislation aims to balance Bolivia's reality—where over 500,000 children already work, often in extreme conditions—with international treaties. The government hopes it will help eradicate extreme poverty, though the International Labour Organisation (ILO), which sets a minimum working age of 14 for developing countries, is reviewing whether the law breaches child labor regulations. Garcia argued that stricter laws aligned with international conventions would be unenforceable given Bolivia's specific circumstances.

A 50-year-old woman, O'Donnell, experienced chest aches, nausea, and fever after helping someone, researched "women's heart attack symptoms" online, took aspirin, and visited a cardiologist the next day, who inserted a stent for a 99% blocked artery—a "widow maker" heart attack. She did not call emergency services but warned others via her blog to recognize symptoms and call 911. O'Donnell, known for roles in shows like Drop Dead Diva and hosting the canceled Rosie Show, emphasized heeding internal warnings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, from Harrow, was fatally stabbed during a scuffle in an alleyway near a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, around 00:30 GMT on Saturday, dying an hour later; a 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and remains stable. Police stated Che was invited to the "well-run" party with adults present and was not involved in an earlier altercation when a group of youths tried to enter, but was later targeted. A 21-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of murder, two boys aged 15 and 16 were arrested and bailed until mid-December, and a 14-year-old was held for possessing an offensive weapon. Detectives seek witnesses near the alleyway between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate.

Denmark restructured its cancer diagnosis system after poor survival rates compared to other European countries, particularly due to long waiting times for patients with vague or hard-to-diagnose symptoms. The new model introduced three pathways: fast-track routes for patients with clear "alarm" symptoms, diagnostic centers for those with unclear symptoms (allowing GPs to refer patients for comprehensive tests without specialist ping-pong), and "yes-no" centers offering quick scans for minor symptoms to rule out cancer. This approach, implemented since 2007, improved organization within existing resources, reduced delays (from months to hours in some cases), and boosted survival rates, with Denmark now catching up to Scandinavian neighbors. Wales, with a similar healthcare structure, explored potential lessons from Denmark’s emphasis on GP-specialist collaboration and streamlined diagnostic processes.

Following the UK government's decision to disband the OFT, Powys council won a competitive bid to take over its responsibilities in regulating estate agents, receiving £170,000 annually to issue warnings and bans against agents acting dishonestly or breaching estate agent laws. Complaints will still be handled initially by local trading standards departments, which can prosecute offenders but will refer cases involving breaches of the Estate Agents Act to Powys. James Munro, leading the new Powys team, expressed hope that this role would demonstrate the council's capability to secure more external contracts in the future, discussing the role on Radio Wales.

NHS Employers approved a workforce reshaping plan allowing staff like nurses and pharmacists to take on additional tasks with more training, following a Nuffield Trust review that highlighted existing examples of such role expansions to address junior doctor shortages and GP workload pressures. The report emphasized the need for non-doctor staff to contribute more due to shifting care demands toward long-term conditions, but stressed funding was required for training. While NHS Employers supported the recommendations, unions warned against using this as a quick fix, with the BMA stressing the irreplaceable expertise of doctors and Unison highlighting chronic funding shortages for training.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the A36 Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place outside the First depot following a crash at 03:00 GMT, with the road reopening at 14:00 GMT, causing significant rush-hour disruption and delays to commuters and bus services; investigations into the collision are ongoing, while First reported partial service resumption but anticipated full normal operations by the evening commute, with Managing Director James Freeman thanking the public for their patience and staff for their exceptional efforts in managing the situation.

NRW estimated the Swansea tidal lagoon would cause 21% salmon and 25% sea trout mortality annually during migration, based on "best available evidence," while TLP disputed these figures as lacking scientific basis and claimed NRW refused to share its methodology, instead citing its own modeling showing a 2% worst-case fish mortality. TLP criticized NRW's scenarios as unrealistic and misleading, while NRW defended its evidence-sharing process over 1.5 years and expressed confidence in its assessment, which was reviewed by independent experts. The £1.3bn project, seen as a test bed for larger lagoons, awaits the UK government's unpublished review, with Welsh government support but urgent need for clarity on the UK's position.

Stormont's DETI Minister Arlene Foster announced the creation of an industry-led agri-food marketing body, developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB), to enhance strategic marketing coordination for Northern Ireland's agri-food sector, which supports nearly 100,000 jobs across farming, fishing, retail, and distribution. The body, modeled after Scotland Food and Drink, aims to unite the industry for collective benefit, with Foster highlighting its pivotal role in guiding marketing efforts for both government and private entities. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the initiative as crucial for export-led growth and addressing the need for better marketing coordination, though she noted potential implications for other organizations, including her department, and expressed intent to discuss plans further with AFSB.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a public tree-planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley on Saturday afternoon, inviting locals and visitors to help plant 40,000 native trees as part of a four-year UK-wide project commemorating the millions who died in WW1, specifically honoring the 40,000 from Ireland lost in the conflict. The initiative, under the pledge "We will stand for those who fell," aims to create a lasting tribute with wildflowers like poppies, fostering wildlife and a reflective space. Volunteers are advised to wear sturdy footwear, with limited parking available near Derry city.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award at Harrogate's crime writing festival for her debut novel "Someone Else's Skin," featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome, praised by judge Ann Cleeves as a finely written thriller addressing domestic violence and honor crime, while US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honor for her 23-year career creating pioneering female detective VI Warshawski, credited with transforming perceptions of female protagonists and founding Sisters In Crime to support women crime writers globally.

Mitch Santner, who broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, is set to rejoin the team after the June 2017 ICC Trophy, with director of cricket Steve Rhodes citing his earlier injury as a major setback to the team's qualification hopes. Santner expressed frustration over the injury but enthusiasm about returning to contribute with bat and ball, while Worcestershire also secured Australia's John Hastings as their primary overseas player for the 2017 season across all formats.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed in 2008 on a Kiev dual carriageway by a speeding car with stolen licence plates while hailing a taxi; his wife, Ganna Ziuzina, had returned to a restaurant for a glove. A coroner ruled his death an unlawful killing, citing overwhelming circumstantial evidence, including Ziuzina’s rapid attempts to claim his assets, her sale of his possessions, and her affair with a Ukrainian man. The couple met online in 2006 and married after a four-day engagement. Ziuzina, 19 years younger, avoided the inquest despite "strenuous attempts" to secure her attendance. Ukrainian police initially closed the case but reopened it as a murder inquiry in 2011; it remains active but not actively pursued. Mr. Pring’s family believes he was murdered in a staged hit-and-run to inherit his wealth.

Charlie Fearns from Merseyside urgently requires experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital after his third relapse and a failed initial transplant, with no treatment options left in the UK. An anonymous donor paid for his treatment, leaving his family "ecstatic" and "overwhelmed" by the generosity, as confirmed via a hospital email on Wednesday. Financial clearance has been granted, and treatment will commence as soon as possible, with a start date expected next week.

Apple enhanced its iCloud security by expanding two-step verification to include backups, requiring a four-digit code sent to a trusted device or via Find My iPhone when accessing accounts from new devices, alongside introducing a 14-character recovery key for account recovery, though concerns remain about the key's potential loss or theft. Elcomsoft's software, previously exploited to steal celebrities' photos by bypassing iCloud backups, is now blocked by these changes, as acknowledged by its owner, who also noted new email notifications for backup downloads. Security experts argue two-factor authentication should be the default, not optional, to combat password vulnerabilities, with Apple planning to more aggressively promote its use and stronger passwords, while CEO Tim Cook emphasized improving user awareness.

Dan Groves mentioned that details of a potential deal for Wright to purchase 20% of Billericay Town FC are still pending, with The Sun reporting he may become a club director; the club is eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points from a play-off spot. Wright, a 2011 I'm A Celebrity runner-up, played non-league football for clubs like Lewes and Crawley Town. Billericay, recently acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who stated he was comfortable investing £10,000 weekly, signed former England international Paul Konchesky in early March.

Mr Ashley was summoned to provide evidence on worker treatment at Sports Direct's Derbyshire warehouse following a BBC investigation, with a response deadline of 21 March set by MP Iain Wright's letter. The letter noted Ashley's invitation for the BIS committee to meet at Shirebrook, but the committee insisted on a public Westminster meeting, offering alternative dates which Ashley neither accepted nor agreed to attend. Wright warned that failure to comply could lead to contempt proceedings via the House of Commons. Sports Direct did not comment, though it had previously committed to reviewing worker rights under Ashley's oversight, who also owns Newcastle United.

The report "Putin. War," initiated by murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov and completed by his associate Ilya Yashin, compiles evidence from Russian and foreign media to accuse President Vladimir Putin of orchestrating the Ukraine conflict for personal political gain, despite Russia's denials of direct military involvement. It details Russian soldiers' admissions of being deployed to eastern Ukraine, commanded by Russian generals, with salaries up to $3,000 monthly, and estimates Russia's war costs at 53 billion roubles. The report faces challenges in verification, distribution, and public reception, as many Russians accept Moscow's role, while the opposition argues it aims to boost Putin's popularity, though similar past reports failed to incite significant protests.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was discovered at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday; the 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham died from head injuries, as confirmed by a post-mortem, and a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police, remaining in custody.

Carwyn Jones criticized the UK government for not consulting Welsh ministers on the Article 50 letter before its publication, calling it disrespectful to devolved administrations, despite shared goals like free trade. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defended the government's engagement, citing the Prime Minister's visits and ongoing discussions, emphasizing acting in the UK's overall interests. Theresa May's letter mentioned devolving more powers to Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland post-Brexit, but specifics on which powers (e.g., farming, economic aid) and funding after 2020 remain unclear, with Jones expressing concerns about financial support. A white paper on the Great Repeal Bill might offer further details, though current plans for devolved powers are ambiguous, amid debates over EU fund management in Wales.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night, with Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin condemning the "mindless attacks" on PSNI officers and the community. Police stated they were attacked while carrying out duties and appealed to parents to be aware of their children's locations and activities.

Mr. Charney, founder of American Apparel, was ousted following employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds, with the board stating he would not return; his lawyer denied allegations, claiming privacy invasion and extortion. Court filings revealed evidence of illicit emails and racially derogatory remarks by Charney, prompted by his defamation lawsuit against the company, which cited repeated violations of harassment and discrimination policies, deeming him an unacceptable risk to shareholders. The company recently obtained a restraining order barring Charney from disparaging it publicly or seeking board removals.

The upcoming basketball game between Great Britain and Greece at London's Copper Box will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website/app from 17:30-19:30 BST, marking GB's only home game before EuroBasket 2017 in September. Greece won their previous encounter 92-64 in Patras, but will be missing three players for this rematch. GB guard Teddy Okereafor highlighted the importance of the game for EuroBasket preparation and anticipated a great atmosphere, especially for debutants. Following this match, GB will participate in a four-team tournament in Poland as their final warm-up before EuroBasket qualifying in Istanbul.

The narrator recounts covering the 2007 iPhone launch, initially struggling to access the device before securing a brief demo with Apple's Phil Schiller for a BBC report, which drew criticism for overhyping the product; defending the coverage, they compared the iPhone's potential impact to the Model T Ford, later acknowledging its actual transformative role over the next decade—putting powerful computers in billions of hands, disrupting industries like photography (contrasting a poor 2007 SLR photo with a superior 2017 iPhone image taken by the same person), and enabling instant sharing and mobile functionality beyond calls/texts through its intuitive interface, crediting Steve Jobs' vision for sparking the mobile-connected era despite initial skepticism.

Several cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, died after ingesting antifreeze, with tests confirming the toxic substance in all affected animals. Seven-month-old Meereen died on Monday, following three other cats in the past week and another two weeks prior. Meereen's owner, Adria Pearce, described finding the cat foaming at the mouth and vomiting before it died three days after veterinary confirmation of antifreeze consumption. The RSPCA is uncertain whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate, and inspector Andy Bostock urged residents to safely store chemicals and check for antifreeze leaks or spills, particularly during its peak usage season.

Despite the Syriza government's agreement to implement harsh austerity measures, including VAT increases, pension cuts, and privatizations—policies it once opposed—there are no significant protests in Greece, possibly due to public anticipation of details on Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras's concessions for a €86bn bailout. Tourism is booming, contrasting with the severe economic crisis marked by bank closures, credit shortages, and collapsing business confidence, which threatens retail operations ahead of Christmas. Tsipras remains popular despite failing to end austerity, as Greece's near-collapse in July seemingly forced acceptance of creditor demands. However, the bailout's success hinges on creditors, particularly Germany, offering substantial debt relief (30-50%) to provide hope for recovery, avoiding triumphalism over Greece's capitulation.

Ross Kemp is briefly returning to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for Dame Barbara Windsor's final episodes, where her character Peggy Mitchell will be killed off after her cancer returns. Kemp, last seen in the role in 2006, agreed to reunite with on-screen brother Phil (Steve McFadden) to film emotional scenes airing in spring, marking Peggy's death and the Mitchell brothers' reunion. Grant, a legendary character since 1990 known for dramatic storylines like affairs and family conflicts, will return to Walford to say goodbye to his mother and reconnect with past relationships, with producers highlighting the significance of the brothers facing their loss together.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and murdered Alice Ruggles in October; her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, immediately suspected Dhillon upon being notified by police. The trial revealed Dhillon's obsession with the 24-year-old, while Dr. Hills expressed guilt for dismissing her daughters' fears days before the attack, believing authorities had the situation under control. The parents established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise stalking awareness, aiming to honor her vibrant, cheerful personality. Dhillon, 26, received a minimum 22-year sentence after being convicted of murder despite his denial.

EDF approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point C nuclear plant, with Chinese investors covering one-third of the cost, but the UK government unexpectedly delayed final approval for further review, causing uncertainty and criticism. Critics raised concerns over environmental impact, escalating costs, foreign government involvement, and EDF's financial stability, highlighted by board and executive resignations citing excessive risk. The project, expected to supply 7% of UK electricity, faced delays despite EDF's claims of industrial benefits and job creation, with environmentalists advocating for renewable alternatives and criticizing the high guaranteed energy price. The postponement followed Brexit, straining Anglo-French relations and halting major investment momentum.

The newly-designed divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person a spouse committed adultery with, though the Ministry of Justice clarifies there is "no obligation" to provide it. Family lawyers express concern that including a third party increases conflict and complexity, potentially delaying proceedings and raising costs if the named individual responds or ignores paperwork. While the updated form states naming is "not normally necessary," some lawyers fear petitioners may still fill in the box due to its presence, despite warnings that judges disapprove of involving new partners. Statistics show adultery accounted for 12,148 of over 100,000 divorces in 2015, with "unreasonable behaviour" being the most common reason. Lawyers often advise against naming third parties to avoid portraying petitioners negatively.

The passage highlights a conflict in Wales between commercial forestry and environmental policies, where ministers are criticized for prioritizing environmental aspects like native broadleaf trees and public access over timber production, despite Britain being the world's third-largest wood importer. Confor, representing the forestry industry, warns that 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001 and stresses the need for replanting to meet demand, with current planting rates (90 hectares last year) far below the required 20,000 hectares annually to achieve government targets. The industry, split between Natural Resources Wales and private companies, contributes over £450m yearly to the Welsh economy but faces challenges like difficult harvesting conditions, transport conflicts with rural communities, and bureaucratic hurdles for new woodland creation. The Welsh government seeks a balance through initiatives like Glastir and its Woodlands for Wales strategy, aiming to integrate environmental, economic, and social benefits, though industry representatives argue commercial forestry is undervalued compared to "sexier" environmental priorities.

A boy was seriously injured after being struck in Coatbridge, prompting emergency crews to respond to Bank Street near Langloan Primary School around 16:40; he was transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition remains serious.

Russian Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko awarded Ushakov medals to Arctic Convoys veterans, including Able Seaman Charles Lewis, after the UK Foreign Office initially blocked the move due to rules prohibiting foreign medals for events over five years old. The Russian Embassy highlighted the convoys' critical role in supplying the Soviet Union during WWII, enabling the defeat of Germany on the Eastern Front, despite enduring extreme conditions, U-boat attacks, and significant losses—104 merchant and 16 military vessels sunk, with over 3,000 Allied deaths. Veterans like Lewis expressed humility, echoing Churchill's description of the missions as "the worst journey on earth." Following a 2012 Russian proposal and UK creation of the Arctic Star medal, the Foreign Office granted an exception in 2013, allowing President Putin to present the Ushakov medals, awarded for courage in defending Russia.

HM Inspectorate of Probation identified significant delays and lax enforcement in offenders completing court-ordered unpaid work ("community payback"), with one case showing only 16 hours completed over 17 months, prompting 15 recommendations for improvement. The Ministry of Justice accepted these, committing to act on issues like ensuring timely attendance and consequences for non-compliance. While inspectors noted some high-quality work and offenders gaining skills or positive attitudes toward desistance, challenges persist in organizing individuals with chaotic lives, balancing sanctions to avoid imprisonment, and shifting perceptions of unpaid work beyond mere punishment. The report criticized inconsistent delivery and enforcement, urging tailored objectives and urgent remedial action to enhance rehabilitation and public confidence in community sentences.

The comedian faces accusations of hypocrisy for advocating economic and political revolution to aid the poor while living in a luxury London home, highlighted by a Sun headline and a Channel 4 News interview where he dismissed a reporter's question about his rent as "snide" and walked off. Brand, who has previously acknowledged the inevitability of such criticism, defends himself by admitting his wealth and past mistakes but argues that systemic change is essential beyond individual wealth-sharing, which he calls a "sweet, futile gesture" without broader reform. He contends that focusing on his hypocrisy distracts from urgent issues like economic disparity and ecological disaster, using the hashtag #TheSunLogic to criticize the accusations while considering legal action against The Sun and Rupert Murdoch, though he hasn't confirmed it.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated the human genome mapping through competitive methods, drawing criticism from the scientific community, and later pioneered synthetic life with the creation of Synthia. Born in 1946, his early lack of academic focus shifted after serving as a naval hospital orderly in Vietnam, which instilled urgency and a drive to pursue medicine. Excelling in research, he worked at the NIH in the 1980s, developed faster gene-sequencing techniques by targeting RNA, and faced criticism from peers like James Watson. After leaving NIH in 1992 due to funding disputes, he founded private institutes, sequenced the first free-living organism’s genome in 1995, and launched Celera Genomics in 1998 to complete the human genome ahead of the public project. Despite controversy over data-sharing practices, his wealth enabled independent research. He later led ocean microbe genome collection and achieved synthetic life breakthroughs, aiming to revolutionize industries and environmental sustainability.

A survey commissioned by England's School Food Trust, involving 1,000 parents, found that 80% of children eating school lunches tried foods at school they hadn't eaten at home, with half of parents reporting their children requested these foods at home. Carrots, sweetcorn, and peas were the most popular vegetables, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were least liked. The research was prompted by concerns from Mumsnet that parents chose packed lunches due to perceived fussiness. School Food Trust chairman Rob Rees and Mumsnet co-founder Carrie Longton highlighted school meals' role in encouraging dietary variety through peer influence and healthier, diverse options, noting compliance with strict nutritional guidelines. About 40% of primary and fewer secondary school children in England eat school lunches, compared to 46% in Scotland. The online survey ran from February 26 to March 5 among parents of children aged 4-17.

Álvaro Morata, 23, joined Juventus from Real Madrid in 2014 with a reported €30m buy-back clause for Real, after scoring 10 goals for them following his debut at 18. At Juventus, he scored 27 goals in two seasons, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias, and featured in consecutive Champions League finals—coming on as a substitute in Real's 2014 victory and scoring in Juventus' 2015 loss to Barcelona. At Euro 2016 with Spain, he scored three goals, having been linked with Arsenal and Chelsea.

Wilson rejoined Nottingham Forest from Celtic for £2.5 million in August 2013 but was released in May and is currently without a team; the 30-year-old made 51 appearances during his second spell at Forest, having previously spent four seasons there before joining Celtic, and also had spells with Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world's third-largest retailer, is exiting the US market by transferring most of its loss-making Fresh & Easy chain to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity firm run by Ron Burkle. Approximately 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will move to the new business, while the remaining 50 stores will close. Tesco will provide an £80m loan to Yucaipa as part of the deal, which costs Tesco £150m overall—partly recoverable if the loan is repaid. The Fresh & Easy chain, operating 200 stores across California, Nevada, and Arizona, has been unprofitable since its 2007 launch. Tesco retains an option to buy a stake if Yucaipa turns the business profitable, following Tesco's first annual profit decline in 20 years reported earlier in the year.
He faced racial abuse but overcame it, discussed his journey with BBC Sport's Nick Hope, briefly considered competing for France, and is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

The French Alps glaciers have significantly retreated from approximately 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to about 275 sq km by the late 2000s, representing a 26% loss over 40 years, as documented by Marie Gardent and colleagues using map archives, satellite imagery, aerial photographs, and manual verification to address challenges like debris cover and shadows. The retreat, presented at the American Geophysical Union meeting, is uneven, with southern regions like Belledonne and Ecrins Massifs experiencing the most severe losses—Belledonne glaciers nearly vanished, and Ecrins retreat was over three times faster than the northern Mont Blanc Massif, attributed to lower elevations and drier climatic conditions in the south compared to the north's higher precipitation and cloud cover. While La Mer de Glace, France's largest glacier in the north, slightly decreased from 31.5 sq km to just over 30 sq km, the overall Alpine trend mirrors accelerating glacier loss reported in neighboring countries like Switzerland.

The Scotland women's football team has won all five qualifiers and faces Iceland in a crucial match that could secure their place in the upcoming finals, avoiding past play-off heartbreaks experienced in Euro 2013 and the World Cup. Both teams are unbeaten, with Iceland ranked 20th globally, and their head-to-head matches will likely decide the group winner. Scotland is well-positioned for automatic qualification as one of the best runners-up if needed. Forward Claire Evans highlights the emotional stakes, Iceland's strength, the importance of home support, and the benefits of having 12 squad members playing abroad—including herself at Bayern Munich—where exposure to top leagues like Germany's enhances the national team's competitiveness through diverse experiences and training environments.

Stuart Campbell was arrested in west England following a harassment complaint by a woman in her 30s from south London, alleging online harassment over two years; he was released on bail pending mid-September inquiries. Campbell, a Scottish independence campaigner and blogger behind Wings Over Scotland, stated the allegations involved non-threatening tweets still publicly visible, denied any threatening content, and accused media (specifically The Herald) of using innuendo to fuel speculation. The Metropolitan Police confirmed investigating the complaint, while Campbell announced reduced posting due to "reasons totally outwith [his] control."

PETA advocates replacing Skegness's Jolly Fisherman mascot with a fish named "Skegness - A Happy Plaice," arguing the current mascot symbolizes animal cruelty in fishing, while Skegness Mayor Carl Macey acknowledges the suggestion but defends the beloved mascot's positive image, noting it will be reviewed by the council but emphasizing its historical significance since its 1908 creation by the Great Northern Railway to promote tourism with the slogan "Skegness is so bracing."

Scotland defeated Georgia in a rugby match, initially trailing after Vasil Lobzhanidze's early try but quickly taking control with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg before halftime, alongside Greig Laidlaw's conversions. Hamish Watson extended Scotland's lead early in the second half, but Lobzhanidze scored again from a Georgian scrum. Despite Georgia's scrum dominance causing issues, including a yellow card for Scotland's Moray Low, Hogg secured his second try and Scotland's sixth in a counter-attack, with Laidlaw contributing multiple conversions. Scotland's coach Vern Cotter praised the first-half performance and team management, noting challenges in the second half. The final score reflected Scotland's 38-11 lead before Georgia's second try and Scotland's late surge.

Widnes secured a victory over Castleford despite a late comeback attempt, leading 14-6 at halftime with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge, countered by Paddy Flynn's try for Castleford. Widnes extended their lead to 38-12 in the second half through additional tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (twice), and Joe Mellor, who capitalized on a Castleford error from a short kick-off. Castleford responded with three tries in four minutes—Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn's hat-trick score—but fell short, suffering their fourth consecutive home league defeat. The result moved Widnes above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remained sixth, one point ahead.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti detained at Guantanamo Bay since 2002 following his arrest in Pakistan over alleged al-Qaeda and Taliban links (which he denied), was released after a US review panel concluded he no longer posed a "continuing significant threat." He had challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court and was flown home on a Kuwaiti government plane, with his lawyer expressing joy over his release. The Guantanamo Periodic Review Board determined in July that his continued detention was unnecessary, though he must spend at least a year in a Kuwaiti militant rehabilitation center as part of his release terms. Kuwait had advocated for the release of its detainees; al-Odah maintained he traveled to Afghanistan and Pakistan for Quranic teaching and humanitarian work. He is the first inmate freed since May's Taliban-US prisoner swap, reducing Guantanamo's population to 148. The facility opened in 2002 post-9/11, and President Obama has repeatedly pledged to close it.

The viral song "PPAP" (Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen), performed by fictional character DJ Piko-Taro (played by Kazuhiko Kosaka), gained global popularity due to its catchy beat, absurd lyrics, and simple dance, amassing over 4 million views on YouTube and 44 million on Facebook via 9GAG. While it drew international attention and comparisons to Psy, with numerous covers and tributes from celebrities and social media influencers, it received mixed reactions—some found it amusingly addictive, others irritating—and limited traction in Japanese media despite its creator attributing its origin to spontaneous playfulness.

Thousands attended the Anzac Day dawn service at Hyde Park Corner and a parade of up to 400 people preceded wreath-laying at the Cenotaph, commemorating the first major World War One battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces. A Westminster Abbey service featured the national anthems of both nations, echoing the first 1916 London commemoration attended by King George V. These events honor sacrifices in all wars, drawing expatriates and visitors. Australian High Commissioner Alexander Downer reflected on the Gallipoli landings' courage and heroism. Veterans, service personnel, and families participated in the Cenotaph parade, watched by crowds including expats, with schoolchildren reading prayers and three national anthems performed. The eight-month Gallipoli campaign, a bloody allied attempt to defeat the Ottoman Empire, was central to the remembrance.

David Clarkson, 30, rejoined Premiership Well in July and may debut for St Mirren against Alloa in the Championship, having scored nine goals for Dundee last season but mainly featuring as a substitute this term. He emphasizes his fitness through U20 matches and training, aiming to contribute as St Mirren sits eighth, seven points above bottom-placed Alloa. With two Scotland caps (one goal) and nearly 400 senior appearances for clubs including Bristol City and Brentford, Clarkson stresses the importance of winning games to build confidence and climb the league table.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan, with initial concerns about the workers' pension scheme being addressed through productive talks between Unite union and Boparan's representatives, resulting in guarantees that all current agreements, including the existing alternative pension scheme (active since the final salary scheme closed in 2004), would be honored under new ownership. Boparan's office confirmed the continuation of current pension arrangements, and Unite highlighted the new owner's aim to restore profitability via increased investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity to process chicken in addition to turkeys.

A council meeting addressed issues with the new Cowes chain ferry, which launched in mid-May but faced breakdowns, groundings, suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues, and vehicle damage. Council leader Dave Stewart announced free crossings until 2 July to acknowledge problems and gather feedback, ordered an audit review, and described the start as "frustrating and disappointing." Local businesses, like Angie Booth's shop, reported significant trade losses, prompting questions about compensation similar to that for damaged cars. Transport councillor Ian Ward stated compensation was under discussion, downplayed the situation as prototype "teething problems," noted resolved electrical issues and seamanship-related groundings, and mentioned council-authorized ramp extensions to prevent vehicle scraping.

The passage discusses Brexit's impact on the UK fishing industry, noting that while fishing communities strongly supported leaving the EU to escape the unpopular Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and regain control over UK waters, a House of Lords report warns they risk being marginalized in negotiations due to the sector's small economic contribution (0.5% of GDP, 12,000 jobs). Challenges include shared fish stocks with EU states, reliance on EU exports, and potential trade-offs where continued market access might require allowing EU boats into UK waters. The report advises retaining some CFP elements, like science-based quotas, and highlights risks of fragmented management across the UK’s four nations post-Brexit. Despite concerns, industry representatives express optimism about future autonomy and sustainable management, citing recent quota increases as positive indicators, while the government views Brexit as an opportunity to reform fisheries policy.

Timothy Geaney admitted to taking or permitting images of partially dressed young boys in erotic poses (without sexual activity) between 2004 and 2014, leading to a community payback order, placement on the sex offenders register, and mandatory participation in a sex offender program in early 2024. The General Teaching Council Scotland subsequently removed him from the teaching register, deeming his conduct "fundamentally incompatible" with the profession as it condoned child exploitation, noting the prolonged pattern of offending (10 years), the volume of images, and lack of remedial action, which indicated a high risk of recurrence. The panel found him unfit to teach, banned him from reapplying for two years, and he did not attend the hearing.

A fire on 2 March at a Duncan Street site operated by Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited (managed by Asset and Land Group) caused travel disruptions and led the Environment Agency (EA) to revoke the firm's environmental permit, suspending waste acceptance and requiring waste removal, effective 7 August pending appeal. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) noted the site was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law despite nine visits in 12 months, but raised concerns in February about potential fire impacts, prompting joint EA-GMFRS inspections and the EA's enforcement action. The fire's cause remains undetermined.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated Syria is committed to destroying its chemical weapons per the UN-backed timetable but missed a deadline, citing attacks on a shipment by "terrorist groups" during transport to Latakia. He defended Syria's actions amid US criticism of barrel bomb attacks in Aleppo, which activists claim killed hundreds, including children, though Mekdad denied targeting civilians and accused the US of supporting terrorists. Conflicting reports emerged about Aleppo’s central prison, with rebels claiming control and freeing detainees, while state media denied the seizure. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only 4% removed so far, prompting US and Russian concerns over delays; Mekdad reiterated Syria’s commitment to meeting deadlines despite security challenges acknowledged by the OPCW.

England secured a decisive victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series with a day to spare, marking their second-biggest win by runs against Pakistan. Joe Root was named man of the match for his exceptional performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, alongside taking four catches and a wicket, after addressing previous batting errors. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's responsibility and control, while coach Trevor Bayliss highlighted his dedication. Analysts Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott lauded England's dominant display, noting Pakistan's broken spirit and poor shot selection, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the series. Misbah acknowledged Pakistan's confidence issues but remained hopeful for improvement. The third Test is scheduled for 3 August, with Vaughan predicting a tight series despite England's strong position.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is gathering experiences from older people, their families, and friends about residential care to inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies as part of her review into quality of life and care in Wales. The review will assess factors like health, social relationships, and care home environments, involving consultations with care providers, staff, and public bodies. Rochira aims to highlight both good care practices and address concerns about inconsistent care quality. Care Forum Wales supports the review's goals but criticizes the lack of care provider representation on the advisory panel, viewing it as a missed opportunity for sector engagement.

Paul Sheerin, a 39-year-old former Aberdeen midfielder who has been Arbroath's player-manager since 2010, was appointed to replace Neil Cooper at Aberdeen after a relegation season that saw Arbroath drop to Scottish League Two in 2013-14. Aberdeen CEO Duncan Fraser stated manager Derek McInnes selected Sheerin following a thorough process, with Arbroath chairman John Christison accommodating Sheerin's move despite wanting to retain him. Sheerin, who played for multiple Scottish clubs and Sweden's Östersunds while earning a Scotland U-21 cap in the mid-1990s, led Arbroath to their first national trophy—the 2011 Scottish Third Division title and promotion.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Swansea's upcoming match following Bob Bradley's dismissal, with the club seeking a swift appointment, preferably ex-Derby manager Paul Clement, to avoid relegation amid concerns about the Championship's growing competitiveness and the difficulty of immediate promotion if relegated. Curtis reflects on Swansea's rise from near-bankruptcy and lower-league struggles to Premier League stability under managers like Roberto Martinez, Brendan Rodgers, and Michael Laudrup, but notes a decline since Laudrup's 2014 departure, citing frequent managerial changes, dilution of the "Swansea Way," and inadequate player replacements. Despite this, he believes the current squad can survive, emphasizing the club's history to new signings via the documentary "Jack to a King" to underscore the importance of staying up for both the club and the local community.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated human genome mapping through competitive, controversial methods, facing criticism from the scientific community while achieving significant milestones like the first complete genome of a free-living organism (Haemophilus influenzae) and co-publishing the human genome. His Vietnam War service as a naval hospital orderly instilled a lifelong urgency, driving his medical career and innovative approaches, such as focusing on RNA to expedite gene sequencing, which drew criticism from figures like James Watson. After leaving the NIH due to funding issues, he founded private institutes (The Institute for Genomic Research, Celera Genomics, and later the J. Craig Venter Institute), leveraging commercial resources to pursue ambitious projects like creating the synthetic organism Synthia, announced in 2010. He also led global ocean genome sampling via his yacht, Sorcerer II, and championed synthetic biology's potential to revolutionize industries, reduce oil dependence, and mitigate environmental damage.

The Sutton Trust report highlights that England's apprenticeships are often low quality and too short, with fewer than 200,000 of 520,000 annual starts at Level 3 (A-level equivalent), compared to Germany's 570,000 predominantly Level 3 apprenticeships for young people. It notes only 20% of English employers offer apprenticeships versus 51% in Germany, and 11 young people compete per apprenticeship, with over half of apprenticeships since 2010 below Level 3 and three-quarters targeting over-25s already employed. The report calls for 300,000 new apprenticeships yearly, mostly Level 3 or higher, lasting at least three years, and reducing Level 2 courses to 10%, arguing this would boost social mobility and economic competitiveness. The Association of Colleges supports prioritizing Level 3 but stresses preserving respected Level 2 apprenticeships in sectors like construction, while the Department for Education cites ongoing reforms to enhance rigor, employer responsiveness, and minimum duration.

Sarah Storey, Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals (11 gold, eight silver, three bronze) across six Paralympics in cycling and swimming, won a race in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska, and aims for further success at the Rio Paralympics. Having won four golds at London 2012 and 21 world titles across both sports, Storey, who began her career in swimming with six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before switching to cycling in 2005, could secure her 17th title in an upcoming road race.

Hereford United (the Bulls) were expelled from the Conference Premier due to unresolved financial debts, primarily £148,000 owed to football creditors including former manager Martin Foyle, players, and staff, despite multiple deadline extensions granted by the Conference. The club, taken over by Tommy Agombar in June, failed to meet the final deadline of 12 June, leading to their expulsion and Chester's reinstatement. This followed a dramatic final-day escape in April where Hereford stayed up, but their financial crisis worsened with total debts around £225,000, including £70,000 in unpaid taxes. The Hereford United Supporters' Trust had offered to buy the club for £1 and clear debts, but the bid was rejected. Financial decline accelerated after relegation from the Football League in 2012, with attendances halving since 2009.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, earned 61 senior England caps after debuting in 2009, participating in two World Cups and two European Championships but playing only three minutes at Euro 2016. He announced his international retirement, citing "common sense" and wishing success to manager Sam Allardyce and the team. Milner holds the record for most England Under-21 caps (46, debut 2004) and scored his sole international goal in a 5-0 World Cup qualifier win over Moldova in 2014.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, died at his Cambridge home after a months-long illness, with a private funeral planned and a memorial service to follow. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it for 30 years across six continents and producing over 200 recordings, including the first complete Mozart symphonies on period instruments and a celebrated 1980 Handel’s Messiah. Educated at Cambridge and mentored by prominent musicians, Hogwood held early roles with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and the Early Music Consort of London, later serving as artistic director for the King’s Lynn Festival and Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society, while teaching at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell. Tributes highlighted his generosity, academic brilliance, and foundational role in historically informed performance, with colleagues like Christopher Purvis, Richard Egarr, Emma Kirkby, and David Thomas praising his legacy, influence on musicians, and genial personality.

A boy from Northern Ireland, whose identity is protected, was removed from mainstream schooling in June due to difficulties coping, leading his mother to quit her job to care for him. His family requested a special school placement but were told all schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full, with no timeline for availability. The boy’s mother highlighted his distress at being isolated while his siblings attend school. Recently, the family learned an additional classroom assistant was hired at a local special school, potentially enabling his enrollment soon. She expressed concern about systemic capacity issues affecting other families, noting schools are oversubscribed. The Education Authority declined to comment on the case, citing privacy, but stated it is reviewing special school place needs in Northern Ireland to ensure local availability, with ongoing work aimed at placements from 2016 onward.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) has made a takeover bid for Newport Gwent Dragons, intending to prioritize Rodney Parade as a rugby venue, but Newport County Football Club holds a lease until 2023 with fixture primacy if they remain in the Football League, which chairman Foxall insists must be honored. A WRU takeover vote is scheduled for May 9, while Newport RFC chairman Godfrey states County and Newport Squash Club are protected under current agreements, though the WRU's plan to install an artificial pitch conflicts with Football League rules. Newport County, battling relegation, is two points clear in League Two with two games left and could secure survival this weekend; relegation would be a major setback after their 2013 promotion.

The passage recounts the harrowing experiences of a former child soldier in Sierra Leone's civil war, who was kidnapped by rebels at 15, endured brutal initiation and violence, and later escaped to Freetown where he turned to crime before being rehabilitated by a preacher's project. This led to his involvement in combating the 2014 Ebola outbreak through community education in local languages, food distribution, and establishing a treatment unit, saving many lives despite initial resistance and fear. He now focuses on rebuilding the nation by investing in youth, reflecting on his transformation from causing atrocities to contributing positively.

Approximately 80,000 items from the Wedgwood Museum faced auction to cover pension debts from Waterford Wedgwood plc's 2009 collapse, but a public campaign swiftly raised the required funds, allowing the collection to remain at the Staffordshire museum. Administrators Begbies Traynor confirmed the sale's completion, with the Art Fund transferring the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum before loaning it back. The museum had entered administration in 2010, and a 2011 High Court ruling permitted the sale to reimburse the Pension Protection Fund. Stakeholders, including Alison Wedgwood and MP Tristram Hunt, highlighted the collection's cultural significance and relief at preventing its global dispersal.

Dan Groves mentioned that details of a potential deal for Wright to purchase 20% of Billericay Town FC are still pending, with The Sun reporting Wright would become a club director; the club, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division and three points from a play-off spot, was recently acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who stated he was comfortable investing £10,000 weekly, and signed former England international Paul Konchesky in March, while Wright, a 2011 I'm A Celebrity runner-up, has non-league football experience with clubs like Lewes and Crawley Town.

Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England, unexpectedly announced a one-year extension to his term until 2019, deviating from the anticipated choices of leaving in 2018 or staying until 2021, with the decision driven primarily by personal family considerations—his daughters' education timelines in Canada—rather than political pressure or Brexit-related economic concerns. While acknowledging the professional challenge of departing mid-Brexit negotiations (with Article 50 expected to conclude by 2019), he emphasized his commitment to the role until his family’s planned 2018 return, dismissing speculation about tensions with the government or reactions to criticism of the Bank’s pre-referendum forecasts.

Blackpool took an early lead through Jamille Matt's close-range finish from Nathan Delfouneso's cross, but Colchester United equalized via Kurtis Guthrie after a goalmouth scramble from a corner. Blackpool goalkeeper Sam Slocombe made crucial saves, including denying George Elokobi just before halftime, while Guthrie hit the bar from two yards. Tom Aldred missed a late headed chance for Blackpool, and Colchester's Sean Murray received a straight red card for a foul in injury time, ending the match 1-1.

The Healthy Me programme, developed by Northern Ireland's Action Mental Health, targets P6 and P7 pupils to help them manage stress during educational transitions, particularly the move to secondary school and transfer tests. Piloted in five schools, it offers interactive workshops teaching emotional wellbeing awareness, coping strategies like breathing exercises, and identifying support sources, while also training teachers. Carrick Primary School launched the initiative, with pastoral care coordinator Helen Hamilton noting reduced anxiety among pupils and parents despite challenges like larger secondary school environments. Chief executive David Babington emphasized preparing children for modern stressors, citing a slight rise in 2016 transfer test entrants (14,681). Chief inspector Noelle Buick highlighted the urgent need to strengthen youth resilience through preventative education amid evolving social challenges.

The disused Fawley power station chimney, a 198-meter structure operational from 1971 to 2013 and capable of powering one million homes, is set to become the tallest attraction south of London's Shard as part of Fawley Waterside's £1bn "merchant city" redevelopment. The project, planned to start construction in 2018 pending outline permission, includes a petal-shaped glass structure, marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth, with the chimney retained as a signature feature due to its existing infrastructure and iconic status on the Solent skyline.

At the Hong Kong championships, GB's Rhys Latham won bronze in an unspecified event, chasing down Poland's Adrian Teklinski (gold) and Germany's Lucass Liss (silver), marking GB's second medal after Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch. GB's men's team pursuit lost the bronze to Italy, while the women's team pursuit finished fifth. Joe Truman exited the men's keirin semi-finals, and Katy Marchant was eliminated early in the women's sprint but remains set for the time-trial and keirin. Commentators Chris Boardman and Sir Chris Hoy praised Latham's tactical race and strong finish. Despite the women's team pursuit missing medals, Barker highlighted their youth and potential for growth towards Tokyo 2020, with Joanna Rowsell Shand noting their inexperience and promising futures. Marchant expressed disappointment but viewed the event as part of her Tokyo preparation.

Ross Kemp is briefly returning to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for Dame Barbara Windsor's final episodes as Peggy Mitchell, whose character will die from cancer in spring 2016 after her surprise return to Albert Square. Kemp, who last played Grant in 2006, agreed to reunite with on-screen brother Phil (Steve McFadden) to film emotional farewell scenes, citing his close friendship with Windsor and the significance of the storyline. Executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins highlighted the Mitchell brothers' iconic status, noting their turbulent history—including Grant's affair with Phil's wife Kathy—and framing their reunion as a showcase for Kemp and McFadden's acting during Peggy's final moments.

Sadio Mane scored two quick goals as Liverpool defeated Tottenham, with manager Mauricio Pochettino criticizing Spurs' lack of desire and readiness to compete for the Premier League title, particularly in a poor first-half performance. Pochettino warned that Chelsea could extend their lead to 12 points with a win over Burnley, exacerbating Spurs' challenges. Tottenham's away form against top-six teams has been dismal, with just two wins since late September and only one victory in their last 17 such matches. Former player Danny Murphy highlighted Spurs' defensive disorganization, attributing it partly to switching from their usual back-three formation against top sides to a back four, and noted a significant contrast between their strong home performances and struggling away mindset.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 declared governor posts in Nigeria's elections, marking the Peoples Democratic Party's (PDP) worst defeat since 1999, following its presidential poll loss to APC's Muhammadu Buhari, who will be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP lost key northern states, including Katsina, Kaduna, and Boko Haram-affected Adamawa, but retained Rivers State and won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east.
