Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model known for appearing in Ricky Martin's "Livin' La Vida Loca" video, denied Italian media reports claiming she attempted suicide, attributing her hospitalization to collapsing from low blood pressure after a domestic fall that caused bruising; she refuted her boyfriend Luigi Mario Favoloso's alleged suicide comments, clarified he was in Naples during the incident, and stated she was recovering at home, while the passage also notes her past marriage to Fabrizio Corona, a jailed paparazzo convicted of celebrity blackmail.

As Kate and William await their second child, a YouGov poll reveals the British public favors the name Diana for a girl, with 12% support, honoring William's late mother, followed by Alice and Charlotte at 9% each; for a boy, James (13%) and Alexander are preferred. A quarter of the 2,200 respondents hope for a girl, while only 3% want a boy, and social media users express strong sentiment for the name Diana. Additionally, 68% support William's planned six-week paternity leave.

A suicide bomber attacked protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 people and injuring 64, including an Afghan lawmaker participating in the demonstration against the provincial governor; the Taliban denied responsibility, and no other group claimed the attack, which occurred around 10 a.m. local time.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona after rejecting the club's final contract offer, a three-year extension contingent on him playing 60% of matches, as confirmed by his agent and ex-wife Dinorah Santana, who stated negotiations are over and criticized the club for delaying renewal talks until April. The 31-year-old right-back, who spent seven successful years at Barcelona winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League titles, will depart the Nou Camp this summer.

Pablo Osvaldo, currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton and performing well with three goals in six games, has publicly urged Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentine club, believing their South American-style play and abilities would make them perfect fits for Boca and that fans at La Bombonera stadium would enthusiastically welcome them, as he expressed in an interview with Corriere dello Sport, highlighting their exceptional careers—Pirlo as a world-class midfielder and Totti as a Roma icon.

Amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson, 18, suffered only a minor nose cut despite a dramatic double somersault fall from horse Merrion Square during a Wincanton race, with the viral video attracting hundreds of thousands of views online. Undeterred, he resumed riding immediately, describing the incident as a blur and recounting fellow jockeys' horrified reactions to the replay. Ferguson humorously accepted the online attention and banter, joking about pursuing gymnastics post-racing while acknowledging his luck in escaping serious injury.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain and England flanker, dressed as Iron Man and shared the image on Instagram coinciding with the release of "Avengers: Age of Ultron," captioning it with movie-related hashtags. Haskell began his career at Wasps in 2002, earning his first England cap in 2007, then played for Stade Français (2009-2011), Ricoh Black Rams in Tokyo (briefly post-2011 World Cup), and New Zealand's Highlanders (12 appearances) before returning to Wasps in 2012. Since his return, he has surpassed 100 appearances for Wasps and earned 57 caps for England.

The wide-leg trouser is a key SS15 trend, offering an alternative to skinny jeans with styles like denim, cropped, printed, or striped, appealing for its effortless look. Styling tips include pairing with high heels to elongate the legs, keeping tops simple to balance volume, and opting for high-waisted, long lengths for added height. Denim is highlighted as the easiest entry point, showcased by brands like Gucci and Topshop (with their Miller jean), while Celine and Stella McCartney presented dressier versions. The trend, revisiting 1970s fashion, suits spring regardless of weather and has been embraced by figures like Louise Redknapp and Poppy Delevingne.

The University of Michigan reversed its decision to cancel a screening of "American Sniper" after over 200 students petitioned against it, citing concerns over negative depictions of the Middle East and its impact on the local Arab-American community, while a counter-petition prompted officials to reinstate the showing. Vice President E. Royster Harper acknowledged the initial cancellation was a mistake, emphasizing the university's commitment to free expression and student choice, and offered "Paddington" as an alternative screening, a decision supported by football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists allegedly ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter, directing flames at a quokka on Rottnest Island near Perth, Western Australia, on April 3, singeing the animal which survived; detectives seized video evidence, evicted the men (aged 18 and 24, residing in Cockburn Central) from the island, and charged them with animal cruelty, with a court appearance scheduled for April 17. Quokkas, cat-sized marsupials, inhabit islands off Western Australia, including Rottnest and Bald Island.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer who performed in 1930s and 1940s New York venues like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar alongside stars such as Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra, had never seen footage of herself dancing as her films, photos, and memorabilia were lost over time. Filmmaker Mark Cantor and volunteers compiled a video of "soundies"—early music videos—featuring her performances and showed it to her at her nursing home, where she expressed delight, calling it "fabulous."

The tradition of washing one's own car in Britain is declining, with a third of men and three-quarters of women never doing it, and only 12% of men washing their cars regularly. Fewer than 5% involve their children for pocket money. Factors include Sunday shop openings, live football, the rise of hand car washes, and larger vehicles like 4x4s being harder to clean. Easter saw 15 million cars washed by owners, though a quarter did it to escape the house. Regional differences show Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield residents wash cars most frequently, while Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh residents do so least. Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are most often owner-washed, while Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes are least. An OSV spokesman attributes the decline to time constraints, bigger cars, lack of child participation, and affordable alternatives like automated or hand car washes.

Martin Skrtel praised Steven Gerrard's significant influence since joining Liverpool in 2008, crediting him for helping him settle at the club and describing him as still one of the world's best players, synonymous with Liverpool. Gerrard, set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, aims to lead Liverpool to the final on his birthday (May 30) before departing for LA Galaxy. Skrtel acknowledged the challenge of replacing Gerrard but expressed confidence in existing players stepping up with team support. Both Skrtel and Gerrard are returning from three-match bans for the Villa match.

At 75 years old, Jack Nicklaus achieved a hole-in-one on the 130-yard fourth hole during the Masters' par-3 contest at Augusta National, witnessed by playing partners Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw and celebrated by the crowd. This marked his first ace at Augusta, part of a record-tying five hole-in-ones that day, including two by Camilo Villegas, who ultimately lost the contest to Kevin Streelman in a playoff. Nicklaus, the youngest Masters winner in 1963 and a six-time champion, is among five golfers to complete the career Grand Slam, an achievement Rory McIlroy could match with a victory.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas as storms produced multiple tornado reports, including one near Goddard and three near Aetna, with the Goddard storm moving northeast and posing risks to other areas. CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers noted the danger of nighttime tornadoes. Missouri also saw impacts, with a possible tornado in Potosi causing wind damage, flooding, fallen trees, and hail described as "baseball size" by a Twitter user. Aerial footage showed roof damage and flooded streets in Potosi, while dark clouds were reported nearby. More storms were forecast for Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris during an April 2 arrest, claiming he mistakenly used a gun instead of a taser; a judge permitted him to vacation in the Bahamas, prompting criticism from Harris’s family, who viewed it as apathetic. Bates’ preliminary hearing is set for July 2, with his lawyer emphasizing a focus on courtroom facts. Harris’s family alleges Bates was unqualified and received preferential treatment due to donations and friendship with Sheriff Stanley Glanz, while the sheriff’s office denies claims that supervisors were told to forge Bates’ records; Bates’ lawyer released training documents to assert his qualifications. Two deputies involved in the arrest were reassigned over safety threats.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title fight against champion Jose Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas, unveiling a new tiger stomach tattoo alongside his existing gorilla chest tattoo, captioning it ominously on Instagram. McGregor claims Aldo lacks motivation to defend his title for an eighth time, citing Aldo's reluctance during their promotional tour where McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt in front of 5,000 Dublin supporters, intensifying their already fractious rivalry ahead of the bout.

Tony Abbott faced criticism from anti-drinking campaigners and cultural studies professor Julie Robert after skolling a beer at an Australian Rules function, with critics arguing he glorified binge drinking and linked masculinity to excessive alcohol consumption. Robert highlighted the problematic nature of such displays, suggesting they promote a culture prioritizing speed and quantity over social drinking, while others, including Health Minister Sussan Ley, defended Abbott, emphasizing his fitness habits. The incident, where Abbott downed a schooner in six seconds amid cheers, sparked debate over irresponsible drinking stereotypes and the evolving public concern about binge drinking, contrasting with past attitudes exemplified by figures like former PM Bob Hawke.

Indiana has experienced a significant rise in HIV cases in Scott County, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary cases linked to intravenous drug use, primarily involving the painkiller Opana, far exceeding the county's typical annual rate of five cases. Governor Mike Pence approved a temporary 30-day needle exchange program, distributing over 5,000 clean syringes and collecting 1,400 used ones, but its extension beyond April 25 is uncertain due to Pence's opposition to such programs as anti-drug policy. Health officials expect case numbers to rise with increased testing, and lawmakers are debating legislation to allow needle exchanges in other high-risk counties, though concerns about promoting drug use and federal funding bans pose challenges. The program's sustainability is questioned, with critics emphasizing the need for long-term solutions to prevent similar outbreaks.

An obsessive Arsenal fan created a detailed exam about the club for his girlfriend Saskia, who scored 43.5/50 (87%), prompting him to humorously declare he wouldn't dump her. The test included multiple-choice questions, squad listings, and opinion-based sections, with strict instructions and feedback marked in red pen—Saskia was criticized for errors like misidentifying player positions but praised for creative answers, such as calling Eden Hazard a derogatory term. She shared the test on Twitter, sparking mixed reactions: some users hailed the boyfriend as a "legend" and Saskia as "proper gf material," while others deemed the test excessive, mocking him as a "biff-head." Despite struggles with specific questions (e.g., naming all 11 starting players), Saskia’s performance, including citing Thierry Henry’s legacy to justify Arsenal’s greatness, secured her an "A" grade and relationship reprieve.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level Medellin cartel member, fled Colombia in the 1980s fearing for his life and became a DEA informant for 27 years, aiding in high-profile prosecutions like those of Carlos Lehder Rivas and Manuel Noriega, with the promise of U.S. citizenship as compensation. Despite his significant contributions, including global undercover operations, the DEA did not grant him citizenship, leaving him illegally in the U.S. after declining health forced his retirement. Now facing deportation, Toro fears assassination in Colombia, citing his role in dismantling cartel operations, and lives in limbo without a green card, passport, or Social Security benefits, relying on a former DEA handler’s financial help while his temporary visa has expired. He asserts he has atoned for past crimes and demands the citizenship he was promised.

A 14-year-old Indian girl from Uttar Pradesh's Mathura district is fighting for life with 70% burns after self-immolation following an alleged gang rape by five village men, which occurred when she went outside to relieve herself; her family reportedly urged silence. The accused were arrested amid heightened sensitivity to sexual violence in India, referenced alongside the banned documentary "India's Daughter" about the 2012 Delhi gang rape and murder of Jyoti Singh, whose case sparked nationwide protests and death sentences for perpetrators. The passage also describes vigilante justice incidents, including mob killings of men accused (but not convicted) of rape, such as Ibo Cha and Syed Sarif Khan, reflecting public outrage over sexual assault.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal has ruled Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw out of Sunday's derby against Manchester City due to insufficient fitness, despite Van Persie declaring himself fit, and emphasized the importance of controlling aggression after their previous 1-0 loss to City. Van Gaal expressed his dream of winning the match, which could secure third place and automatic Champions League qualification, surpassing preseason goals, while acknowledging City's challenge and praising the unwavering support of United's fans.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested high ticket prices by leaving seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match at Emirates Stadium, with the cheapest tickets costing £64—among the league's highest—despite the Premier League's recent £5.14 billion TV rights deal. Organized by fan groups including Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906, supporters displayed banners inside and outside the stadium criticizing the disparity, such as "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket" and "Football without fans is nothing." Protest leaders Kelvin Meadows and Roy Bentham condemned the "extortionate" prices, warning that football risks alienating working-class fans unless costs align with incomes, with further protests planned post-match.

A newborn baby named Star Reader from Barnsley, West Yorkshire, was diagnosed with life-threatening biliary atresia, a rare condition where bile ducts are blocked or absent, shortly after birth. Initial surgery to unblock her bile ducts failed, necessitating a liver transplant for survival. Neither parent was a suitable donor, but Star’s maternal aunt, Shanell Reader—her mother’s twin sister—donated part of her liver without hesitation. The transplant, performed in November, was successful, allowing Star to recover, though she requires lifelong anti-rejection medication and regular liver function tests. Biliary atresia affects about 1 in 16,000 newborns and can be fatal without treatment; Star’s parents expressed profound gratitude to Shanell, who emphasized her unwavering commitment to saving her niece.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Aké, Loïc Rémy, and Willian participated in Audi's football challenge, competing in three rounds: first firing balls into a car boot (Hazard/Aké won 5-3), then playing over an Audi R8 V10 Plus acting as a tennis net (Hazard/Aké won again, leading 6-0), and finally shooting from long range into a convertible (Rémy/Willian won). During the final challenge, Willian accidentally smashed a wing mirror off an Audi, with Rémy reacting in dismay, though neither had to pay for damages.

Robert Dellinger, a 54-year-old former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, was sentenced for causing a December 2013 highway crash that killed Vermont couple Amanda Murphy (24, eight months pregnant) and Jason Timmons (29), along with their unborn baby, by driving his pickup truck over 100mph across a median into their SUV. Despite initially telling investigators he was attempting suicide, Dellinger later denied being suicidal during sentencing, where he pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault for the fetus’s death, facing 12-24 years in prison. His defense cited Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drug overdose, Prozac effects, and advanced multiple sclerosis, while prosecutors noted he argued with his wife over medications before the crash. Dellinger’s wife testified about his character, and he wept in court; he also faces a wrongful death lawsuit, with his attorneys emphasizing his prior "productive and exemplary life" before health issues led to his departure from PPG Industries Inc. with a $1 million severance.

Lacey Spears of Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for murdering her five-year-old son Garnett-Paul by poisoning his feeding tube with salt; her ex-husband Chris Hill publicly wished her harm in prison, criticizing her lack of emotion during sentencing. Prosecutors argued Spears caused her son's prolonged suffering and death to seek attention, evidenced by her social media posts detailing his medical issues, while her defense claimed innocence and blamed hospital negligence, planning an appeal. The judge noted Spears had a mental illness but deemed the crime "unfathomable in its cruelty," with prosecutors highlighting her exploitation of the boy's illnesses for self-aggrandizement.

The arrival of Australia's influenza vaccine is delayed by a month due to the inclusion of protection against two new strains, H3N2 and B/Phuket, which caused increased deaths in Europe and the US during the northern winter as the previous vaccine was ineffective against them; high-risk groups, including the very young, elderly, and most Indigenous Australians, will receive free government-funded shots from April 20, while experts urge everyone to get the updated vaccine, which is now a better global match and will also be used in the upcoming northern winter, to protect vulnerable populations.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb face criticism from National Geographic magazine, which described the site as lacking historical character and having an "incongruous art deco style," alongside concerns over Illinois' proposed budget cuts that threaten the state historic preservation agency managing the tomb. Governor Bruce Rauner's plan to eliminate the agency coincides with the 150th anniversary of Lincoln's assassination, exacerbating fears about reduced staffing, operational hours, and future management. Despite recent renovations totaling over $2.5 million, including interior upgrades and waterproofing, supporters argue the critique is unfair, emphasizing the tomb's excellent condition and historical significance, while visitors and officials defend its impressiveness despite the negative portrayal.

The resurgence of 1990s and early 2000s fashion trends, including chokers, berry lips, round sunglasses, and Calvin Klein logo shirts, has sparked both enthusiasm and criticism, particularly with the potential return of JNCO's wide-leg jeans. The passage highlights nine controversial trends that some argue should remain in the past: bucket hats (worn by Rihanna and Christina Aguilera), camouflage print (popularized by Destiny’s Child and Jourdan Dunn), extreme styling like double denim (Victoria Beckham and Kylie Jenner), Ugg boots (Paris Hilton and Kristen Bell), Daisy Dukes (Jessica Simpson and Miley Cyrus), Juicy Couture tracksuits (Britney Spears and Nicki Minaj), colored sunglasses (*NSYNC and Cara Delevingne), corsets as outerwear (Victoria Beckham and Selena Gomez), and harem trousers (Kim Kardashian and Elle Macpherson).

Four rainbows appeared in New York after heavy rain, photographed by fashion CEO Amanda Curtis; China is cracking down on exotic dancers performing at wakes; Robert Downey Jr. became agitated during a UK interview about his private life; the Kardashians sparked the #KylieJennerChallenge lip-plumping trend using jars; 102-year-old Alice Barker "time-traveled" via film; a prom-posal controversy led to racism accusations; Ewan McGregor will play Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast'; Johnny Depp transformed for 'Black Mass'; a pregnancy announcement referenced 'Fresh Prince of Bel-Air'; and a military dad creatively photobombed his son.

Serena Williams celebrated her 700th career victory at the Miami Open with a giant cake, following Andy Murray's similar celebration for his 500th win, after defeating Sabine Lisicki 7-6, 1-6, 6-3 in the quarter-finals to advance to the semi-finals; Williams avenged her 2013 Wimbledon loss to Lisicki but missed a potential match against sister Venus, who lost to Carla Suarez Navarro, and will instead face Simona Halep, who defeated Sloane Stephens 6-1, 7-5.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani human rights activist known for promoting free speech, technology, and progressive values through her Karachi café, The Second Floor (T2F), was assassinated by gunmen after hosting a discussion on Balochistan's insurgency—a topic previously banned at a university. Mahmud, celebrated for her courage in addressing silenced issues despite past death threats, was a national symbol of humanism and tolerance; her death sparked widespread grief. Her café, a hub for secular discourse and artistic expression, attracted youth seeking intellectual freedom. Police have not identified the killers or motive, and her mother, injured in the attack, survived. Tributes highlighted her role in fostering dialogue in a repressive environment.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu healer and West Pakistan Refugee (WPR) who fled to Indian Kashmir during the 1947 partition, has lived for 70 years without citizenship rights—unable to own property, vote in state elections, or access state jobs—leaving three generations of WPRs in abject poverty. Around 100,000 WPRs, mostly in Jammu, face similar exclusion due to pre-independence laws tying citizenship to ancestral ties to undivided Kashmir and state fears of altering the Muslim-majority demographic. Recent political shifts, including Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Hindu nationalist BJP party joining Kashmir’s ruling coalition, offer hope for normalized status, though activists warn of potential unrest if demands for "state-subject rights" are unmet. Despite Kashmir’s relative prosperity, WPRs remain marginalized, with their children barred from state colleges and government employment, fueling frustration and calls for equality amid ongoing regional conflict.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a summer move to Chelsea, who have made a £4 million offer with plans to loan him to Vitesse Arnhem, but Muto prioritizes joining a club where he can play regularly and develop. His former coach Ranko Popovic praised Muto's intelligence, speed, strength, and confidence, highlighting his unique potential. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho acknowledged awareness of Muto but refrained from detailed comments, noting that while commercial interests, like Chelsea's partnership with Yokohama Rubber, influence transfers, the club only targets players with genuine talent or prospects.

The passage criticizes England's policy of not selecting overseas-based rugby players for the national team, contrasting it with Australia's decision to drop such restrictions, which allowed top performers like Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell to rejoin the Wallabies. It argues that England's stance is outdated, citing examples like Steffon Armitage and Nick Abendanon, whose games improved significantly after moving to French clubs, and Jonny Wilkinson's success abroad. The author contends that excluding elite players based on their club location weakens England's World Cup chances, as tournaments should feature the best available talent, and urges coach Stuart Lancaster to prioritize performance over loyalty to domestic clubs, emphasizing that a home World Cup demands no compromises in squad selection.

Open Garden's FireChat app enables off-grid messaging via wireless mesh networks without internet or mobile signals by leveraging Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) and similar Android Bluetooth features, creating local networks where phones act as nodes to relay data within 30 feet (9 meters), extending up to 200 feet (61 meters). The app, downloaded over five million times, offers "everyone" and "nearby" chatrooms for broad or proximity-based communication, useful in areas like planes or underground, with secure, anonymous messaging via usernames. To address range limits, Open Garden developed Greenstone, an egg-shaped beacon that stores and relays messages, boosting network resilience with a one-year battery life and capacity for 1,000 messages, currently operational within 20 feet (6 meters) with FireChat. Greenstone aims to support communities, events, and emergencies where connectivity fails, though its release timeline depends on manufacturing partnerships.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer, advocates for reclaiming the word "fat" as a neutral, body-positive descriptor, akin to terms like "short" or "wife," rejecting its negative connotations. In her TED Talk, she highlights societal issues such as a 66% rise in workplace size discrimination over 30 years and young girls prioritizing thinness, while citing studies showing increased acceptance of diverse body types through exposure. Her burlesque performances aim to challenge narrow beauty standards by presenting her 240lb body glamorously, fostering empowerment and self-confidence. Despite initial nervousness, performing boosted her body image, and she encourages others to draw on past courageous moments. Though her 2014 talk recently posted on YouTube received some negative comments, it garnered 38,000 views and overwhelmingly positive feedback, including personal stories of body reevaluation, leading her to believe body positivity is gaining ground.

Theo Walcott, frequently benched for most of Arsenal's season, participated in a Lanvin photoshoot alongside teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, Mesut Ozil, and model Olga Sherer, as the fashion house is the club's official tailor. Walcott, named a substitute in 17 of 33 Premier League games, recently played six minutes against Chelsea and aims for his first start since March 14 in the upcoming match against Hull. Arsenal's first team will wear Lanvin attire for the FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30.

A collection of over 400 Hollywood props and puppets created by legendary makeup artist Rick Baker, valued at approximately $746,100, will be auctioned on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on Propstore.com. The items, spanning Baker's 30-year career and including pieces from films like *Men in Black*, *Batman Forever*, *How the Grinch Stole Christmas*, *Gremlins 2*, *Planet of the Apes*, and Michael Jackson's *Moonwalker*, feature notable lots such as the Alien Edgar Bug ($40,000), the Grinch costume ($8,000), a Two-Face mask ($1,500), and a Harry suit from *Harry and the Hendersons* ($6,000). The auction offers fans and collectors a chance to own original items from more than 50 productions, with Prop Store highlighting its significance as a no-reserve sale directly from Baker's Cinovation Studio.

A seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, died after falling 164ft in the French Alps during a family ski holiday in Flaine. Described as a daring, outgoing, and competent skier who started at age three, Carwyn became separated from his mother and sister on their last run, ventured into dense woodland, and fell. His mother desperately searched for him, but footprints and sliding marks in the snow led investigators to his body. The family expressed profound devastation, calling Carwyn an "adorable, caring" child whose death left a "vast void." The community in his Welsh hometown, Talybont-on-Usk, mourned his loss, with his school and local leaders offering tributes. Carwyn, who admired adventurer Bear Grylls, is believed to have headed toward the resort visible through the trees, removing his skis before the fatal fall. His body awaits repatriation while the family remains in France.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia at age 13 due to societal pressures to achieve a "size zero" figure, exacerbated by bullying about her weight. She restricted herself to one piece of fruit daily, hid food, lied about meals, and consumed as few as 100 calories a day, leading to severe health deterioration, including a slowed heart rate and collapse requiring hospitalization and a week on a heart monitor. After receiving support from eating disorder organizations and mental health services, she began recovery. Laura has since spoken about the pressures young girls face regarding body image and reached the semi-finals of Miss Teen GB, a competition promoting body positivity and rejecting size-zero stereotypes.

Raheem Sterling faced Liverpool fans' demands to stay during the unveiling of the club's new New Balance home kit at Anfield, part of a record £300 million four-year deal replacing Warrior. Despite Sterling recently rejecting a £100,000-a-week contract and expressing interest in Arsenal, Liverpool insists he will not leave, with fans applauding calls for his retention. Players including Daniel Sturridge, Simon Mignolet, and Martin Skrtel participated in the launch, discussing the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa and the importance of winning for the club's future. The kit features a gingham design, white branding, and a Hillsborough disaster tribute. Philippe Coutinho's recent match-winning performance and Steven Gerrard's potential farewell in the FA Cup final were also highlighted.

University of Manchester researchers, led by Dr. Sarah Bridle, have created the largest high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4% of the sky using data from the Dark Energy Survey's 570-megapixel camera on the Victor M. Blanco Telescope in Chile. The map, presented at the American Physical Society meeting, visualizes dark matter clumps (red for denser, blue for sparser) and aims to expand to 12.5% of the sky by 2018, enabling a 3D view. Dark matter, comprising 80% of the universe's matter, is detected via gravitational lensing effects on light from galaxies. The team analyzed 130 million galaxy images with supercomputers to measure distortions, supporting theories linking galaxy formation to dark matter concentrations. The survey will further study dark energy's role in cosmic expansion by comparing dark and visible matter distributions.

Manchester United have officially approached PSV Eindhoven to sign 21-year-old winger Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal, familiar with Depay from their time together in the Netherlands' 2014 World Cup squad, keen to secure him as a key summer signing. PSV's technical director confirmed contact from United, Paris Saint-Germain, and another major European club, noting significantly higher transfer fees than Tottenham's rejected £15 million bid from the previous year. Depay, enjoying a prolific season with 20 goals in 26 league games, helped PSV clinch their first Eredivisie title in seven years. Known for his pace, dribbling, and powerful right foot, he has drawn comparisons to Arjen Robben and was deemed by a scout to be more advanced than Cristiano Ronaldo at the same age, despite occasional decision-making inconsistencies. Depay also scored twice for the Netherlands during their third-place World Cup finish in Brazil.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 victory over Manchester City's youth team in the Youth Cup final, with Tammy Abraham scoring two first-half volleys and Dominic Solanke adding a late third goal to solidify the win. Key performances included Chelsea's Ola Aina and Jake Clarke-Salter excelling defensively, while Ruben Sammut anchored the midfield effectively. For Manchester City, captain Tosin Adarabioyo stood out in defense, and Brandon Barker created chances but missed opportunities, including Isaac Buckley-Ricketts' equalizer. City struggled with injuries, notably Kean Bryan's early setback, and wasted critical chances from Aaron Nemane and Manu Garcia, ultimately failing to overcome Chelsea's dominance.

Marco Rubio stated that people are born with their sexual preferences and that it is not a choice for most, but he opposes same-sex marriage as a constitutional right, believing marriage should be defined as between one man and one woman, with states—not courts—deciding through legislation. He expressed willingness to attend the same-sex wedding of someone he cares about despite personal disagreement, comparing it to his Catholic view that divorce is wrong but not a reason to stop loving someone. Rubio, who recently announced his presidential run, has reportedly secured over $51 million in financial commitments for his campaign against other well-funded Republican candidates.

Pablo Mandado, a 27-year-old Spaniard, and Ilze Zebolde, a 31-year-old Latvian, quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to embark on an open-ended cycling journey with no fixed agenda, aiming to explore the world affordably. Over 356 days, they cycled nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries, starting in London and traversing France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, the Balkans, Greece, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia, with plans to continue through Asia and the Americas. Living on less than €3 each per day, they minimize costs by camping (161 nights), using hospitality platforms like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers, and relying on cheap or free food sources like pasta, seasonal produce, dumpster diving, and occasional invitations. Their main expense is food (€2.74 daily), while their gear-heavy journey symbolizes a pursuit of discovery and the unknown.

A Texas couple hired attorney Cathy Hale to sue James Evans, owner of Premiere Photos, alleging racial slurs were printed on their 2012 wedding photo booth pictures, discovered months later by the bride’s sister, who delayed informing them to avoid ruining the event. Evans denied the allegations, refused to apologize, and challenged the couple to sue, prompting a lawsuit under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract. Evans claimed no evidence linked his company to the slurs and asserted the couple showed no mental anguish, while Hale stated her clients seek an apology, not monetary compensation. Mediation is scheduled, with a trial possible in July if unresolved.

England full-back Mike Brown is adopting a cautious approach to his concussion recovery, uncertain of his return date after withdrawing from Harlequins' match against Saracens, emphasizing the importance of recognizing symptoms through World Rugby's online modules, which helped him prioritize health over playing in key games like England vs. Ireland. He aims to avoid prolonged absences like Johnny Sexton (12-week break) or George North (ruled out for the season after four concussions), stressing the dangers of ignoring symptoms and urging teammates to do the same, while discussing his experience in Land Rover's "We Deal In Real" campaign.

Smartphone use and constant internet connectivity may be contributing to a decline in sexual frequency among British couples, with research indicating a drop from five times a month in 1990 to three times currently, as noted by Cambridge University statistician Professor David Spiegelhalter. He attributes this trend to eroded boundaries between work, home, and personal life due to technology, leading to busier lifestyles and less dedicated time for partners. Factors like increased solo living and competing priorities, such as checking work emails late into the evening, further reduce intimacy, leaving individuals too connected to external demands to focus on their relationships.

Tibetan Mastiffs, once valued at up to £1.2 million in China as status symbols and gifts for influencing officials, have drastically declined in popularity due to the government's anti-corruption crackdown discouraging such gifting and bans on large dogs in major cities. This collapse has led to hundreds being sent to slaughterhouses for meat and leather, often in cruel conditions, with many stolen or discarded by breeders who overbred for profit, causing quality deterioration. Urbanization also highlighted the breed's unsuitability for city life, ending a boom that began in 2005.

A survey of 600 women in Paris revealed that every participant experienced sexual harassment or assault on public transport, with half first encountering it before age 18; harassment ranged from insults and intimidation to rape, causing 60% of women to fear attacks (versus 30% of men). Unreported incidents often forced women to alter routines—changing routes, schedules, or clothing—restricting their freedom and excluding them from public spaces. The report, submitted to France’s Women’s Rights Ministry, prompted calls for campaigns against such behavior, emphasizing education on recognizing abuse, legal consequences (like five-year sentences for assault), and addressing perpetrators' perceived impunity.

Direct Line's #everydayfix competition, in collaboration with Makerversity, tasked designers to create prototypes addressing common daily emergencies identified through a survey of 2,000 people, where the top issues included inability to sleep (46%), losing keys (37%), and traffic delays (35%). Three shortlisted prototypes are Snooze (an alarm clock silencing phone notifications for better sleep), Forget Me Lock (a key-attached device indicating door lock status via color swivels), and Nipper (a compact phone charger using household batteries). Public voting via Twitter retweets by 46 April will determine the winner, which Direct Line will fund through a Kickstarter campaign for development. Other proposed solutions, like a parking space alert pin, a message-relay app for dead phones, and a bone-conduction helmet for cyclists, did not make the final shortlist.

Vera Baird, Northumbria's Police and Crime Commissioner, is under Ministry of Justice investigation for allocating over £500,000 in public funds to Victims First Northumbria, a charity she co-directs with the force's Chief Constable Sue Sim, raising conflict of interest concerns. Critics, including Home Affairs Committee chair Keith Vaz, condemned the decision as inappropriate, labeling it a "soap opera," while Baird defended it as procedurally compliant. Sim, facing prior bullying allegations investigated by Baird, announced her June retirement. The charity replaced a declining service, but sources fear victims may distrust it due to Sim's involvement. The MoJ will determine if conflict rules were breached, potentially ceasing funding.

Three people were sentenced for a brutal assault on Greg Valecce, 53, in Philadelphia, where he was beaten, tied to a chair, and tattooed with offensive symbols over 42 hours in March/April 2014. Corry Campbell, the ringleader, received 20 years; his girlfriend Sandra Ng got 23 months; and Carl Halin also received 20 years. Two others, David Harrison and Jennifer Pratt, await sentencing and trial. The attack stemmed from Campbell's belief that Valecce injured his cat and stole from him. Valecce suffered broken bones, emotional trauma, and offensive tattoos (later removed), including swastikas and derogatory terms. Police found drugs, a tattoo gun, and Valecce's stolen debit card at the scene. All three convicted pleaded guilty to aggravated assault, conspiracy, and false imprisonment.

Manchester United have officially approached PSV Eindhoven to sign 21-year-old winger Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal, who previously worked with Depay during the 2014 World Cup where the Netherlands finished third, keen to secure him as a summer signing. PSV confirmed contact from United, Paris Saint-Germain, and another major European club, noting that current offers involve larger sums than Tottenham’s rejected £15 million bid from the previous year. Depay, enjoying a prolific season with 20 goals in 26 league games, helped PSV win their first Eredivisie title in seven years, scoring a stunning free-kick in their 4-1 victory over Heerenveen. Born in 1994, Depay joined PSV at 12, made his debut in 2011, and has over 100 appearances, showcasing pace, dribbling, and a powerful right foot, though he can be inconsistent. Scouts and PSV manager Phillip Cocu compare his potential to Arjen Robben, while former Manchester United scout Ed van Steijn believes Depay surpasses a young Cristiano Ronaldo. Depay scored twice for the Netherlands at the 2014 World Cup and was nominated for the Best Young Player award.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 away victory over Manchester City's youth team in the Youth Cup final first leg, with Tammy Abraham scoring two first-half volleys and Dominic Solanke adding a late third goal. City's Isaac Buckley-Ricketts equalized temporarily, but Chelsea dominated through strong performances from Abraham, Solanke, defenders Jake Clarke-Salter and Fikayo Tomori, and midfielder Charlie Colkett. City's Kean Bryan battled injury and missed a key chance, while Brandon Barker stood out creatively but lacked end product. Chelsea's Ola Aina and Jay DaSilva provided width, while City's Tosin Adarabioyo captained solidly but their goalkeeper Kjetil Haug looked vulnerable.

Marco Rubio stated that people are born with their sexual preferences and that he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer despite disagreeing with it, emphasizing respect for loved ones. However, he believes marriage should be defined as between one man and one woman, asserting that states, not courts, should decide on legalizing same-sex marriage, which he does not consider a constitutional right. Rubio, a Catholic, compared his stance to opposing divorce but still loving divorced individuals. He recently announced his presidential campaign, with donors reportedly committing over $47 million for his primary bid against other well-funded Republican candidates.

Pablo Mandado (27, Spanish) and Ilze Zebolde (31, Latvian), who met in Riga in 2011, quit their Manchester restaurant jobs to embark on an open-ended global cycling journey with no fixed agenda, aiming to explore the world affordably. Over 356 days, they cycled nearly 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) through 16 countries, starting in London and traversing France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia, living on under €3 each daily (€2.99 precisely, with €2.74 spent on food). They minimize costs by camping (161 nights), using free accommodation via Couchsurfing (66 nights) and Warmshowers (44 nights), relying on pasta, bread, seasonal produce, occasional donated meals, and dumpster diving. After symbolically crossing from Europe to Asia via Turkey, they plan to cycle through Asia, cross the Pacific, and traverse the Americas, intending to continue their journey for years.

England full-back Mike Brown is adopting a cautious approach to his latest concussion recovery, withdrawing from Harlequins' match against Saracens and uncertain about his return date, aiming to avoid prolonged absence like Johnny Sexton or Geoff Parling. He experienced post-game headaches after England's France match, attributing his awareness of concussion risks to World Rugby's online modules, which influenced his decision to withdraw from the Ireland Six Nations game. Brown emphasizes prioritizing health over playing, urging teammates to avoid risks, while Northampton's George North faces a season-ending break after four concussions. Brown discussed these issues while promoting Land Rover's "We Deal In Real" World Cup campaign.

Smartphone use and internet connectivity may be contributing to a decline in sexual frequency among British couples, with research indicating a drop from five times a month in 1990 to three times currently, as noted by Cambridge University statistician Professor David Spiegelhalter. He attributes this trend to eroded boundaries between work and personal life, constant email checking, and technological integration, which reduce private time and increase competing demands, leading sex to become a lower priority, a point reinforced by researcher Catherine Mercer's observation that persistent connectivity hinders focus on partners.

Tibetan Mastiffs, once highly valued in China with prices reaching up to £1.2 million as status symbols, have experienced a dramatic decline due to the government's anti-corruption crackdown reducing their use as luxury gifts, city bans on dogs over 50 kg, and urbanization making them unsuitable pets. Overbreeding for profit led to poor-quality dogs, creating a surplus of unsellable mastiffs, while breeders and gangs now send them to slaughterhouses for meat and leather. Recent rescues revealed horrific conditions, with dogs crammed in cages, starved, injured, or dead, highlighting a widespread cruel fate.

Direct Line's #everydayfix competition involved surveying 2,000 people to identify common daily emergencies like sleep issues, lost keys, and phone battery drain, then tasked designers to create solutions, resulting in three shortlisted prototypes: Snooze (an alarm clock silencing phone notifications), Forget Me Lock (a key device indicating door lock status via color), and Nipper (a compact charger using household batteries). The public can vote via Twitter retweets, with the winner receiving Kickstarter funding for development; other proposed solutions not shortlisted included a parking space alert pin, a message-relay app for dead phones, and a cycling helmet with directional audio.
